Her Story is an fmv game focused on combing through footage of archived interviews to solve a mystery. The way you actually search through this footage is pretty interesting. You're able to search for a word, and if that word appears in any of the interviews (which are broken up into bite sized chunks for some reason) then you'll be able to watch that portion of the interview. The game starts you off with the search term 'murder', which produces a few clips that drop hints of other things you may want to look into. The way each clip nudges you to search for certain terms is very well done and you'll find yourself organically going down rabbit holes and having memorable moments when you finally put things together. 

It took me around 40-60 minutes to solve the mystery, and about an hour and a half to hit the credits. I think there was more clips left to see, but it didn't seem necessary to hunt them all down. Overall I enjoyed the experience and liked that the game didn't overstay its welcome. One criticism I'd have is that the game just kind of ends. I solved the mystery and nothing happened, so I just kept on poking around until I reached an ending sequence that as far as I could tell was only prompted by how much time you'd spent in the game (or maybe the amount of footage you'd seen). It would be nice if there was a way you could trigger the ending by making it clear you had solved the mystery, maybe through something serving as a 'quiz' of sorts. 

It was fun, I'd suggest picking it up during a sale and enjoying it in a single sitting. 8/10

Some people pretentiously say that video games are an art form whose language is gameplay. For games to be considered art they would need to communicate a message or an experience through the language that defines it's medium and I'm glad to say Her Story succeeds at everything it attempts to do. It is hard to go into reviewing the game without spoiling something but this is a narrative split in hundreds of clips from 7 interviews from the year 1994. The writing in this game is superb and something many top tier TV shows would strive for as far as script. Many things are ambiguous and you will only take out whatever you put in. The acting was appropriate and the diagetic design around the whole experience enhances the feeling the player will have, especially if he or she had a computer from the era. The way the narrative is delivered reminds me of some of the best detective media I've experienced, particularly Memento. The non-sequential/non-linear and disjointed nature is handled very well.  

Video games as art need to prove that a message can be delivered in a way unique to its format and I'm glad to say this story or experience couldn't be delivered in any other form. In that sense, this is a masterpiece, even if it differs from what our concept of a "video game" should be.

I would encourage anyone to try this game, even non-gamers. Even if I can see some people have valid criticism against the game, I firmly believe this game truly caught lighting in a bottle.

Unraveling the Threads:
Her Story is a game of discovery and deduction, like flipping through a stack of old case files in a dusty archive. As you watch snippets of interview videos, you'll be drawn into a tangled web of events, lies, and secrets that's as riveting as a classic film noir.

The non-linear narrative structure allows you to unravel the story at your own pace, like a detective following leads in a high-profile case. It's an experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat, eager to uncover the truth that lies buried within.

The Art of Interview:
In Her Story, the interviews are the heart and soul of the game, like pieces of a jigsaw puzzle that gradually form a clear picture. You'll analyze the protagonist's words, expressions, and body language, like a seasoned interrogator searching for the truth.

The actress's performance is a standout, delivering a nuanced portrayal that's as captivating as a courtroom drama. It's like watching a masterclass in the art of acting, as each word and gesture holds a clue to the bigger mystery.

A Game of Observation:
Her Story challenges your observational skills, like a seasoned detective scanning a crime scene for vital clues. You'll jot down keywords and snippets of information, creating a mental map of connections and revelations.

The lack of hand-holding adds to the game's charm, as you rely solely on your wits and intuition, like a private eye navigating through the fog of deception. The game trusts you to connect the dots, and the satisfaction of making breakthroughs is as rewarding as solving a locked-room puzzle.

The twist is a testament to the game's masterful storytelling, as it subverts expectations and keeps you guessing until the very end. It's like a magician revealing a mind-bending illusion that leaves you in awe.

Minimalistic Presentation:
Her Story's presentation is minimalistic yet effective, like a seasoned detective relying on basic tools to crack a case. The simple user interface and video archive add to the immersion, as you become fully immersed in the investigation.

The game's understated visuals and atmospheric soundtrack create an eerie and compelling atmosphere, like a fog-shrouded city at night. It's a testament to how less can be more when it comes to storytelling.

Replay Value:
Her Story offers a unique gameplay experience that's as re-playable as a classic puzzle game. Even after you've solved the central mystery, you may find yourself revisiting the interviews to uncover hidden details and alternate perspectives.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Her Story is a gripping and innovative interactive experience that immerses you in a web of intrigue and deception. With its immersive narrative, engaging gameplay, and captivating performances, it's a game that leaves a lasting impression like a haunting melody.

So, if you're ready to put on your detective hat, dive into a labyrinthine mystery, and unlock the truth behind a compelling tale, Her Story awaits you. Remember, in the world of detective work and hidden clues, the journey is as crucial as the destination.

When reviewing Her Story, it's important to dump all pre-conceived notions of "price" and "game" from your mind. Especially because I personally feel that Her Story sets a pretty solid bar for the bare minimum that a mystery narrative should try to accomplish in game form. Yes, you're just "watching videos", but the game lies in that you're only given four pieces of info, the narrative you're intended to solve, and the method by which to navigate your search. You hear the names of people who are relevant to the story and specific details that serve as new "leads", and the search limiter guides you to be more indirect to reward cunning deduction.

Setting aside what you paid, or whether other interactive narratives of this style "did it better" or "did it worse", Her Story is the absolute floor for level of effort for independent mystery games, let alone big name companies. The story was clearly written with care down to the exact vocabulary used to make each script searchable. The narrative was delivered expertly using one actress and a camera. And any mystery game mechanic should be able to measure up to "search engine with a gimmick".

Her Story is a milestone game. It was completely innovative for its time. I cannot recommend it, however, as it was an unsatisfying experience. The premise was good in that you are examining video clips of police interviews in order to solve a crime. It has moments, but your interaction is extremely limited, and you have no other resources except the police interview footage, which is highly edited. Your task then is to categorize the information by tagging the clips, in order to reveal all of the clips. Midgame this becomes rather tedious, and you are still kind of grasping at straws.

Without spoiling anything, there is a lot of speculation about what the true nature of the situation is even once you have revealed all of the tapes. That is not necessarily a weakness, but it is kind of unsatisfying as a detective game. If the game had more than one possible definite and clear ending it would be amazing and interesting for replay. This game lacked some mechanics that would have made it far more engaging and rewarding. The player is merely a listener, ultimately. 

All of that said, the acting was great. I love the idea. Instead you may want to try Telling Lies by Sam Barlow. It is much more compelling, and made a huge improvement on the genre he basically invented.

[h1] It's not too bad. [/h1]

2015 was a different time. The concept of computer nostalgia was totally raw. Windows 10 had just released and it ushered in a new era of technology's dominance in our daily lives. This was all very new, just dawning on us. Sam Barlow hit the note perfectly, when he referred to the game's musical selection: " [It] highlights the gap between the authentic 'fake computer world', and the fact that you're playing a game ". It's also an FMV game, an untapped niche. All of this added together meant that Sam struck the note very perfectly indeed. The rapid sales and the critic's reviews should display that.

Yet, as we evolve from a pupa to a full-grown butterfly in this age of digital dominance, how does it hold up? It feels like a last gasp. Many of the things our main (90s) character finds normal is no longer normal. I was born in 2004, and my generation is now on the center stage. I may hate it, but the fact is we are completely different. It very much has an old-fashioned feel to it (but not nostalgic). I love it, personally. Old-fashion is always the best I say. I appreciate the older, slower style of writing. A bravo for Sam for his success in writing. The dialogue was written extremely well, even with the flaws accounted for. I'd be terrified if I didn't see flaws anyway. I enjoyed the realization of who we are playing as in the end, but it was not played on enough during the actual game. The story left me with questions, none of which were thought-provoking, moral, or philosophical. Perhaps I have been spoiled by Lewis. I do expect a good story to challenge how I view the world or what I believe. Otherwise, it is all fluff, barely more than gossip.

But personally, I believe it would have been [i] much [/i] better if this was a novel instead. The entire game was supposed to be a novel concept, something new to enthrall reviewers and be "different". I am mostly immune to such gimmickry. In all practicality, this does not work out. While I expected all clips to be outside of chronological order, it leads to each clip falling flat. There is very little emotional weight or direction. The experience can quickly move from exposition on the character's sex life, to a short clip on how much sugar the character desires in their tea. It is the movie equivalent of dyslexia, and I find that quite comical. I would be lying if I didn't admit that it was enjoyable. 

I assume the "fun" in this game was meant to be the note-taking after every clip. That fell flat as well. It may challenge someone who is younger or someone who does not retain information easily. For me, it was equivalent to sitting on a bench at a public park and writing down the skin color of those who pass by. If you don't see the pointlessness of that, then perhaps you should stop reading this review.

If this game were a novel, I surely would have read it fully. I expect a novel version could have been more fleshed out, in every aspect of writing. It surely would have held more intrigue, and less chance for the story to be spoiled half an hour in. [spoiler] Yes, I saw the confession clip when I searched "watch". I was half an hour in. I quickly realized they were twins (the tat gave it away) and what had happened. Yet I had none of the second act to fulfill the storytelling experience. I felt very robbed. [/spoiler]

Yet I bought the game, and played it all the way through. How could I not recommend it? Only a fool decides to play a game all the way through just to say it is a bad game. It is a good game. It is a unique, novel idea. It gave me nostalgia, for 2015, when this kind of thing was cool and new. I enjoyed the old-fashion of it. I do hope that Sam decides to switch to writing (books) though.

[b]Yes.[/b]

I'm sorry I waited so long to finally play this.  This is an excellent investigation game and will really make you feel like a detective.

The story here: you are someone interested in a 20+ year old criminal case for which the original interview footage was lost a long time ago.  All you have to work with is a clunky old database containing dozens of short video clips which can be accessed through searching for keywords in the transcript.

The gameplay might be best described as exploration-based; except instead of mapping out the floor plan of a dungeon or searching caves for gold coins, you're searching for puzzle pieces across different moments in time.  Each new video clip has a bit more dialogue on it which might or might not give you a new keyword to unlock more avenues of investigation.

The interface is very simple, but simple does not mean this game is easy.  It's all about your own observational and reasoning skills, your ability to discern what is relevant and what to pursue.

Even after several hours, I finished the game and reached the end credits, but am still compelled to return to the database to find out more of the story.

Depending on how you approach it, you might be able to get to the "end" in half an hour while barely scratching the surface, or you might take hours to pick through and learn all there is to know.  I think this would be a good value at $10, but it's worth noting that the game frequently goes on deep sale and can often be found as part of a bundle. Unconditional recommendation. The following will be a spoiler-free review. 

I've apparently spent 3.5 hours "playing" this game (or "game", as some would say), and for all intents and purposes, I've "solved" the main question or questions (which were never explicitly posed) and I have, to use the word that other reviewers here have written, "beaten" the game after about 2 hours. I'll probably spend a few hours more, just out of fun and curiousity. 

This is by far the least amount of time I have ever spent with a PC game I have liked. If the price tag is too high for this short amount of fun, then by all means pass; quite possibly, if you are stingy enough, you can simply get a Steam Refund after playing 1.9 hours, you'll probably have "solved" the game by then as well. But I would recommend it even at full price. 

Others have mentioned how hard it is to put a "genre" label on this, and others have even claimed (some of them quite angrily so) that "this isn't a proper game". Perhaps not, if by "game" you mean a set of rules by which the player wins or loses after performing certain actions. This game is truly open, almost as open as games you used to play as little children -- spend any time with a 2 to 5 year old and you'll know what I mean. If you can no longer have fun doing something like that in an incredibly artsy and intellectually pleasing setting, then this game will certainly not be for you. 

Ostensibly, you role-play an investigator into an apparent murder. At your disposal is an old computer with some even older renderings of ancient VHS tapes made by police investigators. The lighting, sound and video quality is poor, as to be expected from these ratty recordings. You may search through these old clips and gather what you will: information, if you like, or just interpretation. 

Unlike the Obra Dinn, a masterpiece in narrative mystery puzzle solving, Her Story is both much, much shorter and much, much more open: If there even is "a" story, it's not clear that you have to learn all its parts. It's not clear when the game is "over" -- it's over when you want it to be. There is no goal dictated by the game, it's all up to you. Many players might not like this. I am grateful. 

There is much to say about the quality of the material (despite its poor lighting, graphics, etc.), but not too much without spoilers. Perhaps this is allowed: We are probably used to watching professional actors and actresses perform professional villians in professional studios when we consume the tropes that make up the background for this video game, but this is different: Viva Seifert, the person who portrays the only person we see in the video clips, was a professional gymnast turned musician, not an actress. She is absolutely brilliant, but not in the same way as a Hollywood star would have been. And we are richer for it. Since she is playing a person who is, in some ways, playing a person, and the ambivalences are too juicy to be detailed any further here for fear of spoilers. 

Well worth it.

Sam Barlow's debut experimental game, later enabling him a significant venture into these non traditional gaming/film hybrid experiences, is as experimental as it is, a bit cringeworthy. 

For the sake of others curious, I will say that this review contains minor spoilers. I 'beat' the game with just over 50% of the clips unlocked.

For one thing, the game is mostly well written, the dialogue in it's construction develops it's own sense of themes and it's own sense of pacing, especially as you control it but it can only go so far with said narrative in it's style of presentation and it's progression of said themes. The core gameplay loop although innovative is repetitive, and it's major sense of presentation are these ugly static frames of the same woman in an ugly set, and this is the single camera angle of the film for the entire game. Furthermore, I found the lead actress to be annoying more than anything, as she either overacts or underacts every moment for the whole game. 

What it does accomplish is a rather well-done twist that re-contextualises the experience, and changes the game into a kind of spot-the-difference between the seven interviews. You'll start to investigate the very nature of the character in front of you more intimately to discover the truth. It's intuitive and all done through your own sense of progression, and one of the best parts about the experience. However, when the film's sense of thematic development is listening to a character repeat the word 'fairy tale' and 'princess' ten times in a row, it does get grating, and I hope in Barlow reinvented that gameplay loop in his next two games in a more dynamic and less obvious way.

I understand what it's trying to mimic: a police interrogation, which makes sense and is done to a degree. however, there is no sense of presence for the detectives in the room, as there is not a single piece of spoken dialogue for the detectives, and this doesn't feel any easier when the character directly addresses them. These factors broke my immersion and made the game feel boring, as it does little to vary itself. The actress might change her clothes between interviews, a set of shelves behind her in one interview will vanish in the next. In some clips, props appear, and are sometimes used, but that only goes so far. In one clip, she will become hooked up to a lie detector, but it's used as a cheap gimmick, when the inclusion of a device like that could lead to a different sense of narrative, I wish they kept it for an entire interview.

Furthermore, this tangled web of different subplots isn't hard to really put together. You'll discover the truth easily, and at the same time, I'm kind of glad it's like that, but also wish there was a bit more nuance. Plus that ending where you get a message from 'SB' was a really dumb way to close the narrative, but at the same time I don't know how else you could really write an ending to a game like this. It just feels like, "Hey, you won, good job," as I had found only half of the clips. I might return to the rest and uncover the full narrative but there isn't much to bring me back.

To me this kind of gameplay loop has a great sense of potential, and works mostly well in it's script and sense of discovery, however its failure to deliver a more dynamic and immersive experience really holds this game back. I'm eager to play Barlow's next two games, Telling Lies and Immortality however, and this is only because the hybrid of film-making and gameplay makes for a very interesting artistic experience. 

Play this if you're truly curious, but just don't go in expecting this brilliant masterpiece the game had been hyped up to be. It's more of an experimental blend of mediums, and I do appreciate it for being that.

Been playing this for about an hour and a half and I have to say I'm really impressed. Her Story is a throwback to the old FMV games that were made back in the 90s, only this time it isn't ♥♥♥♥, it's actually surprisingly great. The purpose is to try and find out - by going through archive footage of numerous police interviews with a woman that took place two decades earlier - what happened to her missing husband. This is done through keyword searching, so it's best to play this with a pen and paper handy as a video will throw up another clue or word that could be vital in your investigation.

As an exercise in non-linear storytelling Her Story is incredibly well written and a huge amount of thought has clearly gone into not just the dialogue and plotting, but also into the length of the videos. Some of them can be as short as 3-4 seconds and at first viewing seem absolutely redundant. As you delve further into the archives, however, they can take on a whole new meaning. The actress who plays the subject of these interviews deserves huge credit for her work here, her performance only truly reveals its brilliance the further you progress and you begin to notice her intonation, mannerisms and overall demeanour are all absolutely perfect.

If you're after something truly different, interesting and original then look no further. Her Story is a little gem of a game. Recommended.

This is such a good game. The video clips are cut just right, so that searching related terms to something you just learned about gives you an interesting clip (or usually several), but doesn't show you the entire thing. Limiting the number of videos returned means that you have to dig for really specific search terms; searching for "the" will only get you the first few videos with that word, but will show you that hundreds of videos match your search. And the old school computer that you're using to do your research makes all these gameplay focused limitations make sense in the game world: you feel like you're working around the limitations of the database that you're searching, rather than working around arbitrary limitations set by the developer.

The story itself is charming, but what really makes it shine is how it's delivered to you. You can investigate in any direction you choose, so you may learn about certain events much earlier than I did in my first playthrough, for example, just because you're more interested in those questions or events than I was. Even though nothing I did would change the content of the videos I was watching, it felt like my choices mattered, because they determined how I would experience the story.

Anyway, I highly recommend. If you're worried about how short it is, get it on sale, but it's an excellent investigative non-linear narrative exploration and I enjoyed it a great deal.

130005812.review:
Her Story is a decent enough mystery told in a really unorthodox format... that ironically enough slightly hurts it as a game proper in a couple of ways.

Don't get me wrong, it's an absolute charm to open the game, maybe fiddle around a bit with the virtual desktop (it's comparatively sparse when compared with other device simulations, but it doesn't need more), and then get thrust into the story by the initial prompt and the selection of clips that gets you. From that onwards the process of discovery feels rather natural as you zigzag through the timeline of clips by using the different keywords you pick up (both directly and through association/deduction) from the videos to get a deeper and deeper picture.

Now, one of the game's biggest strengths is also a bit of a weakness: the query system is completely open, only limited by clever scriptwriting to hide some instances past the five clip per query limit. It's mostly satisfying as you mess around with other words which might help narrow down larger queries, but sometimes you accidentally get certain "revelation" clips earlier than what you might want to, sometimes even by just messing about (case in point: if you wonder if searching the game's title hides some Easter egg). Not something inherently bad, but the lack of any sort of gating can lead to a flow that's not the intended one.

And while you can get a large portion of the clips naturally (even if late game queries can be a bit more haphazard, such as searching for specific profanities), completing the database can be a not particularly fun thing. After "beating" the game you get a command which gives you the possibility of finding unseen clips (in order), and while I must admit a few of those contained wors I should have thought of searching earlier, it eventually becomes a slog of microclips with very common words in them (some do give hints for other queries, but they are the minority).

A final minor complaint is that the quote search is not a particularly useful tool. I guess there's a few compound words (or maybe some expected phrases) which can lead better searches with this functionality, but ultimately its specificity clashes with search philosophy of the bulk of the game.

Those are ultimately nitpicks, for the initial experience is ultimately a rather enjoyable one. It's not the best detective game ever nor even the best use of breadcrumb storytelling/worldbuilding, but it sachieves what it seeks out to do: tell a story in a way that "justifies" itself as a FMV. It's always nice when you come across these sort of stories which really wouldn't work if told through another medium.

[b]This review does not contain spoilers.[/b]

Let me start off with saying that I did not finish the whole game. Around two hours into the game, I received an in-game prompt that simply asked me if I understood what was going on. When I replied saying I did (and I did), the credit scroll started. It could also have been due to the fact that I had about half of the clips discovered at that point, according to the database on the in-game desktop. I am not sure if there is a proper ending to the game but to be honest, I am not all that invested into the gameplay or narrative.

The game does not give much of a tutorial. Immediately after loading into the game, you are presented with a window with pre-entered text and are expected to search that term to begin discovering clips. The window cannot be minimised, only exited, and once exited, the game returns to the main menu. It is not obvious that the icons can be double-clicked on which is where the tutorial is located.

The settings are found in-game as well rather than the main menu which is all but empty. The settings are also very limited. You are able to disable the shader that adds the retro CRT look - why anyone would want to do that is beyond me - and a button to "Delete Session Data". Some other players feel this button is ambiguous due to its lack of description as it deletes all progress and hours of their playtime was wasted. So be forewarned.

This is a game where note-taking is strongly advised. So much so that user tags are a feature in the game. I would highly recommend using this feature lest you find yourself running in circles for hours.

As for technical non-issues, I prefer to play games in fullscreen borderless and unfortunately this game does not offer that. It has fullscreen (gross), and windowed (less gross). The issue I had was that the game did not care which monitor I chose for it to open on so I had to manually adjust 3rd party software each time I started the game after moving the window to the correct screen at start-up. It was not difficult, just tedious.

There is not really a way I can recommend this game. It is not bad, but it is not good either. The gameplay is tedious and boring, and at times confusing and frustrating. The narrative is simple and was easy to predict. My own technical difficulties did not do it any favours either.

For the sake of being forced to choose between yes and no in terms of my recommendation for this game due to Steam's lack of a neutral option for reviews, I suppose for the right person, [b]whilst on sale[/b], this could be an enjoyable game, but there are other detective games available that are more immersive and interesting. For no other reason than that, my opinion is neutral.

I streamed Her Story on my Twitch channel, and while I liked the game, I recommend you enjoy the game on your own.

'Her Story' is best viewed as an interactive puzzle, where you're trying to find out what happened with the interviews and the murder the interviews revolve around. The interviews are well-acted, the UI sets a good mood, and the 'search' function is delightful to play with.

However, I have a few small complaints.

My chief complaint is that there is no clear indication as to when you have 'beaten' the game. You can only keep pursuing more clips and more of the story as it is presented. Notably, you have a database which indicates how many clips you have and what's missing, but you cannot click to view the entire sequence of clips as you have unlocked them so far, or even quickly navigate to a clip before a missing section to try and give you ideas of what could come after it. This makes finishing the database nearly impossible without the use of a guide, and can provide an unsatisfying conclusion if you were looking for 'finality'.

If you are going to stream this game, I highly recommend having a copy of a guide handy if you get truly stuck. Without my chat actively coming up with helpful suggestions to jog my memory, I would have really struggled to clear this in a reasonable amount of time (I took about 5 hours, though some of that was idle and engaged in chat with my community).

Personally, I'll give this game a solid 91/100. I actually appreciated that there was no definitive 'ending', and the unique gameplay is something I want to see more of. I knocked points because the lack of clarity around the absence of a true 'ending sequence' stumped me and was not obvious in the game's information, which would have freed me to enjoy the mystery a lot more. (There are some smart choices being made, and they are choices, not oversights - but that doesn't mean I felt they enriched the experience enough to not be worth noting for future players.)

You're supposed to investigate the police interviews of a woman whose husband has gone missing, but it's all cut into pieces with only the answers to the questions saved, and you need to use the worst government server search imaginable even by 1990's standards. It is an interesting framing for sure.
Is the story interesting? Yeah it is, that part I don't fault. The gameplay however, that is where it falters.
I get that this is supposed to be a jab at government systems being the most outdated pieces of trash, loosing metadata and not showing you crucial info it clearly has, and yeah I'll suspend my disbelief, it's part of the puzzle mechanics, and it works on its favour.
[b]However[/b], I will not forgive the user session field, you'll find yourself ordering the clips you find over time. Ok, sounds normal so far. But you cannot slot a new clip between two others, you have to switch them on the timeline, scrambling all the others that come after, and you only have a window of 5 clips, the scroll bar does not have buttons, and the sensitivity of your mouse will be your enemy.
At first it's manageable, you're able to sort the clips even if there's gaps, but there's a total of 271 clips you have to organise. You'll be left with a completely scrambled timeline, and no will to organise when new clip comes along, leaving a big mess that you have to deal with, and not in a fun way.
The game fell apart halfway through all the clips, the UI stopped being trash in the context of the setting and puzzle framing, and it started being trash in the context of the game itself.
Might be a harsh thing to say, but watching a compilation of all the clips in order on YouTube will be a better experience.
It took the crappy UI to a level beyond reason, and I'm left with the first half being enjoyable, and the second having me wish I could still refund this game, such a waste of time.
I am very disappointed with it, it could be better, but it isn't.

[b]This game defies categorisation - it might not even be a game[/b]

So, I have a [strike]few[/strike] lot of games. I'm very particular about how they're organised. I do that kind of thing. I used to keep my CDs in
  1)Alphabetical order by artist
  2)Alphabetical order by album name

back when CDs were a thing. I did the same thing with my DVDs and Blu-Rays back when they were a thing, only by movie name in Library convention - 'the' doesn't count, that sort of thing.

The damned internet and streaming services mess with my Chi something chronic in that regard. I don't get to sort things, maintain order in my life quite the way I used to. But, then I found Steam. One of the best things Steam ever did for me was allow me to group my games into categories. Sure, it automatically sorts things into alphabetical order, but it at least allows me to define the categories into which games were put in order to sort them within that category. I've been very happy with that model up until now.

In that regard - Sam Barlow? You suck. You've broken my Chi again.

Her Story - what the hell is this thing?

The closest I can come up with is interactive fiction, but it's not interactive at all. The only interactive part is how you search the video snippets.

Is it hidden object? Not really, but the mechanics are similar - the main difference is that instead of an object hidden inside a busy picture, you're using text (words) to trawl through a busy video snippet library.

It's not a typing tutor game, but there are similarities with educational games in that I could imagine making some of my post-grads play this game as an assignment in a data mining course on how to organise information and why text mining is never as simple as tool vendors tell your bosses it is (or perhaps I'm just a sadist).

And to top it off you have to tie a full fledged reversi game hidden away to complete all the achievements? Seriously? Does that make this a weird kind of prelude to a board game?

Is this (and stay with me here) even a game at all?

The best possible categorisation is that this is a movie (similar to The Interview starring Hugo Weaving - look it up; if you love this game, you'll love that movie) which has been broken down into snippets that you have to search for in order to watch the damn thing with any kind of progressive sequence.

But - 'Text Based Search Driven Interactive Movie Hidden Object Board Game' doesn't really fit in a category header usefully, and even if I do that, it has a population of 1. Perhaps more if I look at Telling Lies or the new one coming out, Immortal.

I could always just categorise this game as 'Sam Barlow' and move on. The man is (if his games are anything to go by) - unique. This is of course assuming that Sam is short for Samuel, and not Samantha. But I'm betting it's a man because;

1) This game is a STEM professional's worst nightmare - meaning only a STEM professional could have possibly designed it; yes I know that's a stereotype but they exist for a reason - get over it.

2) There's just something about the [spoiler]Apple and Snake[/spoiler] tattoo that screams 'written by a man' to me. Sure; there's about as much science behind that last statement as one would expect to see utilised in the judging of a Yuri Geller lookalike contest, but there it is. Call it a gut feeling.

The thing is, once you get past the way the game / movie / search engine works, the story itself is compelling. The atmospherics that are possible from a simulated Windows 95 screen are simply spectacular. It is a minimalist design that provides a far deeper immersion than should be possible with the simplicity of the interface. The story behind all the video is even more compelling and immersive and the mental health aspects of the dramatis personae is going to keep me from sleeping well for the next several nights to be sure. If my cats start making strange sounds in the middle of the night, it could be weeks. But, I digress.

This is (in many ways) a challenging narrative, and one of the more original stories I've read / watched / searched in... well, ever if I'm being frank. I bought it on special as a filler to get some extra Steam credit thing, sat on it and finally played it, and feel so strongly about it that I'm compelled to write a review about it. That doesn't happen very often. I will say however that there are some things that I've always known implicitly that have been reinforced by this game (or whatever);

  1) Monogamy is the simplest and most efficient state in life
  2) Don't EVER give the same present to two different people
  3) People who look alike NEVER ever ever think alike
  4) Don't bring children into this world unless you mean to; don't develop a sense of humour on this subject, it's too special, important, and worthy of your complete and total responsibility.

Sam - seriously, just keep doing what you're doing. I'd much rather you were making actual movies because what you have to offer on that front is simply amazing, but once you get through the wall of WTF that your creation puts up in front of you, this is a haunting tale that I thoroughly enjoyed.

It's just a shame that it lives in uncategorised in my Steam Library. Just saying.

[quote]Note: Summary above and in-depth, spoiler-free review below. Follow my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42611293-Elysian-Reviews/]Curator[/url] for more![/quote]
 
[h1]Summary:[/h1]
Her Story is a puzzle game with a very unique journey through a series of police interrogations lasting around three hours, exposing a plot that unravels in twists and turns, about a story shrouded in mystery, tragedy, fairy tales, and humour.

[b]Reasons to Avoid:[/b]
- Unique style of game isn’t for everyone.
- No replayability.
 
[b]Reasons to Buy:[/b]
- Creative and intriguing story.
- Very unique gameplay concept.
- Achievements – fairly easy to 100%.
- Great atmosphere.
- Compelling acting. 
- Strong value against the price you’d pay for a film.
- Very interesting protagonist.
 
[h1]Graphics:[/h1]
The graphics were stylised in this game – you are looking at an old computer screen from the 1990s and Her Story did a great job of simulating the old, blocky, ugly software of these bygone times along with the curved glass screen and the horrible reflections they used to give off. 

If that is too hard on your eyes, the game offers a setting to remove it so it looks more like a flat screenshot than the intended effect of you looking at the screen, which removes reflection effects and makes colours both clearer and bolder so everything is easier to see. 

The only other graphical option you have is to disable subtitles. Otherwise, this whole game is basically a video, and that video does an amazing job of recreating the effect of a 1990s-era tape recording. 

Cleverly, the computer screen also reflects the face looking at it sometimes, and lights from the background. This was a detail the game didn’t have to go to, but it really made the image feel immersive, placing me right in the 1990s, trying to crack a crime mystery by surfing a database of interrogation footage late into the night.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
Her Story plays out rather like a Full Motion Video (FMV) – most of the game is watching footage just like you would with a film. However, you interact with the ‘game’ to retrieve various clips from a 250-video database in order to watch, and by so doing you have some choice in how you are exposed to the story. You do this by entering search terms into the database search bar, which will retrieve clips containing that word or tag (if you’ve added tags to watched videos). Most of these clips are between 30 seconds and a minute in length and contain snapshots of wider interrogation sessions that leave you hints and clues to piece together in your pursuit to understand [i]Her Story[/i].

It is not like most FMV games where you are offered choices that affect the outcome of the story in a rather binary fashion, but that you will, depending on which clips you retrieve, perhaps get an impression of a different story altogether – at least for a while. 

Her Story also offers a mini-game within – one of those old pre-installed games you get on old operating systems called ‘Mirror Game’. One achievement relates to it but aside from that, I can’t imagine much of a reason to play it. 

Gameplay is not the strength of this title, though, and not why you’d buy it really. The concept and story are.
 
[h1]Story:[/h1]
This story, unlike most FMVs, is told only through one person. The footage we see is all from the interrogation room, but we are never able to see or hear the officers the protagonist is meant to be talking to. This is an interesting choice on the face of it, but it in no way hampered the telling of the story as the dialogue is well-written enough that if you’re paying attention, there will be context to what’s said in each clip and, as you play on, it becomes clearer exactly what the protagonist is talking about, and what really happened. 

These short insights into the seven interrogations the protagonist endures are brilliantly acted, and the behaviour of the character is an intriguing study across the different interviews. The changes in personality and the way things are said – with what kind of expression or even word choice - for the discerning eyes, tell the story from beyond just the words that are being spoken, and help to make this game feel so much more real and raw in a way that interrogation footage really is, for those of you who have seen it elsewhere. 

Through the confessions of our protagonist – and through them alone – we are introduced to a fairly detailed cast, each often with a distinct role and sense of personality within Her Story that makes the game feel more authentic still. 

Her Story, while not ‘hardcore’ in any sense, also doesn’t hold your hand, and you will have to think to understand the narrative behind the game. Though there are guides if you get stuck, the game offers you no hints, instead throwing you in at the deep end with seemingly no objective in mind aside from watching as much footage as you can and working out what information is important and what isn’t. Perhaps even trying to discern whether something is true, too. 

What I really loved about this story, aside from how unique it was, is that even when it ends, you can still choose how to interpret it. It can take on a new depth depending on whether you read it at face value, or whether you read between the lines. And in a way, even at the end, it still retains that sense of mystery. It’s not that it’s not concluded, or that it’s left wide open – it isn’t. The story comes to a satisfying and rewarding end. But what it actually means is something you can debate about, even then. I would love to be more specific about this, but it would be major spoilers for those who haven’t played the game yet.

[h1]Audio:[/h1]
Her Story excellently captured the sounds of an old 90s PC, from the mouse click sounds when you select something, to the tapping of the keyboard when you type, and those subtle electronic noises the running machine makes. 

The game also went the extra mile with a soft, immersive soundtrack that was queued sometimes after a revelation was unlocked in one of the clips – at least, that’s how it felt. The music stirred feelings of excitement or anticipation, driving me to explore more as the plot was unravelling before me. It was a small thing, but it pushed me on to finish the game in one sitting. 

Towards the end, on the cusp of revealing the truth, you will occasionally hear police sirens in the background, too, which only served to further put me on the edge of my seat. 

Given how minimal it was, audio was used amazingly well in this game to strengthen the sense of atmosphere and even to create feelings of excitement and anticipation nearing the end of the game. There is no orchestral score or ground-breaking atmospheric effects here, but despite that, it worked so well – a sure reminder that sometimes, less is more.
 
[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
The graphical style and audio effects really set the scene well and fully sold the illusion of being up late in the night on an old police computer, surfing through a database to crack a case.

Her Story offers very little replayability, but fortunately for completionists you can get all the achievements in one playthrough. 

I think the story was really good – conceptually unique and told well through the short clips we are able to retrieve from the police database. It was memorable and throughout its duration managed to be interesting, moving, and humorous. The protagonist was intriguing all by herself, but the surrounding story was even more so. 

There are not many games like Her Story, so for the price, if what I’ve written here sounds interesting, I definitely think it’s worth picking up.

A lot of key moments that should have been buried deep and act like big points of revelation can potentially pop up early and spoil the little fun the game provides by simply searching random, common words that spring to mind.

Pros:
[list]
[*]It's sorta innovative I'll give it that. 
[*]Decent twists.
[*]Decent start: Until the game falls apart in to randomly typing words and clicking videos without getting any new relevant bits of info out of them, trying to parse all the info provided was honestly fun.

[list]
[*]Lack of gameplay: This would have worked better as a series. Hell you can literally just script a person playing this, record it, edit it and make a better experience than actually playing this game.
[*]Getting stuck is frustrating and incentivises spamming random stuff until something works.

[/list]

Going in to this I laughed off the idea that the devs bought positive reviews, now I'm not so certain.

In the first 5 minutes of starting up the game, I was already impressed to find that, after viewing a few clips I found by playing around with the database, a video game—asides from 1995's Phantasmagoria—finally managed to implement live-action elements without complicating the gameplay. It was straightforward, yet challenging all the same. Searching through the aforementioned database was incredibly fun, and in a sense, addicting; it never got repetitive to me. The incredible story lying under a simple premise of "watching a woman talk to the police" spurred me on to keep going, and I didn't want to miss even a single detail of it. I won't say much anything it because I don't want to spoil this incredible game for you all, but trust me when I say if I had to make a list of my favorite games based PURELY on story, this would STILL be in the top 3.

Of course, I wouldn't dare leave out the work of Viva Seifert, whose performance as Hannah Smith carries the entire game. It's hard to believe that this is Seifert's first acting role; I was convinced that she was a trained performer of some sort, but it turns out that her profession is in music, and she had never even acted beforehand. I can't even think of another actress I'd rather see in the role, and if this game were adapted into a film or television show that she was brought to reprise her role for, I'm a firm believer that she'd win all the major awards and more.

Nonetheless, everything in this game is incredible and skillfully put together. 'Her Story' earns a 10/10 in my books, and I highly recommend it to people who are looking for something new, exciting yet intricate and story-rich. 'Her Story' has all of that and more.

[i]Originally posted on [url=http://www.dragon-quill.net/christmas-steam-games-2019/]Dragon Quill.[/url] Comments are enabled there.[/i]

This was recommended to me as being structurally similar to Virtue’s Last Reward, a game I enjoyed for being, as described by one reviewer, “A Metroidvania of plot.” I can definitely see the similarities here, though I’d say the structure is actually closer to Zero Time Dilemma.

The premise is this: In 1994, a man went missing. His wife was interviewed seven times by the police. However, the interviews are split into hundreds of short clips. You are given access to a database containing every clip, and have to figure out the right search terms to use to find the clips you need to piece together the story.

The game is a very interesting concept, though I think the puzzle aspect is a bit clunky. See, to prevent you from just searching a really obvious term and blazing through most of the database, you’re only allowed to see the first five chronological clips of any search result; the trick, therefore, is to figure out how to narrow your search to eliminate the clips you’ve already seen. …But of course, it’s pretty hard to do that when you don’t know the contents of the other clips and therefore what you might accidentally eliminate with a narrower search. The game is set up very well: The clips in the initial search result give you a clear set of keywords that you can follow in any order, and there are a number of clear thematic words and plot threads that you can follow up on pretty intuitively. (The interviewee is also wearing different suits in each interview, which allows you to easily distinguish which one the clip belongs to at a glance; I appreciated that.) But I still feel that it’s not user-friendly enough; once you pass a certain threshold (maybe 60-70% of the total clips), it’s really hard to get further without just guessing randomly. Additionally, the clips aren’t actually complete; they cut out the interviewer’s questions, sometimes making it hard to figure out what the interviewee is answering or talking about — made worse, of course, by the purposefully maddening use of pronouns and vague language. There were a lot of times when I went, “Okay, but who is ‘he’? What do you mean, ‘what we were just talking about’?” It’s a clever puzzle technique, but it did make things a bit too hard to piece together, I thought.

(There are also quite a few cheap shots that are clearly just to pad the clip count and make it harder to get 100%; there are several clips of the woman answering questions for a lie detector test, each of which are one second long and contain only the words “Yes” or “No”. How exactly are people supposed to find those naturally?)

I think the game could really have used a feature like automatically slotting viewed clips into a linear timeline — they’re all timestamped, so it’s not like that’s a mystery. I noted down a few important timestamps, but for the most part I just stopped bothering trying to keep track of what was happening in what order.

(I also think I accidentally got to the big reveal before I was supposed to — I prioritized searching for characters’ names, and if you do that for one that sounds innocuous early on you end up unraveling pretty much the whole mystery, likely before you see the foreshadowing for it.)

Overall, I think this was an interesting idea, but it needed clearer means of progression and a few more quality-of-life improvements. And unfortunately, after watching the whole thing in order, I actually do think the mystery works better as a linear story; the non-linearity doesn’t really enhance the experience in the end. I think seeing a single narrative in arbitrary chronological order just doesn’t work. What was cool about Virtue’s Last Reward was how you were given complete but separate narratives that each explored a different facet of the overall mystery plus their own self-contained arcs.

[i]Her Story[/i] is a narrative-driven investigative mystery game. A modern '90s FMV title, this game is propelled by an impressive lead performance and an intriguing, if somewhat hackneyed main story. The short game faithfully captures the experience of delving into long-forgotten files to solve a hidden mystery, though the 

In [i]Her Story[/i], the player investigates the disappearance of a man through police interrogation footage of his wife. Of course, this can't be an easy matter: the footage is split into hundreds of seconds-long clips featuring only the wife, and they can only be found through searching for words spoken by the woman. Also, only the first five chronological results with that term will be displayed. Thus, the player must discern which keywords will produce the most relevant material and piece together what happened.

The two main draws of this game are the performance of the main actress and the intrigue of the mystery. Viva Seifert solidly portrays a woman running through a gamut of emotions amidst family turmoil, and the grainy lo-fi aesthetic helps to sell the authenticity of her role as a suspect in a no-name police precinct. The mystery itself has enough twists and red herrings that it should throw players for a few loops before revealing what's truly at play.

One's enjoyment of [i]Her Story[/i] relies on not expecting much in the way of gameplay, as the most interactivity offered is typing in search terms and tagging videos. This game feels better to "play" than many of the old-school FMV games, though, because it accurately conveys the feeling of sifting through poorly organized records. There's no ludonarrative dissonance in this one. If you're searching for a more traditional detective videogame like an [i]L.A. Noire[/i], however, just be aware that this is far less traditional.

It should take most players around 90 minutes to solve the core mystery. The most relevant search terms are networked throughout the clips that players can take different paths to still find the necessary videos in rapid time. [i]Her Story[/i] has little replay value once the tricks of its narrative are known, so keep this short playtime in mind when deciding whether to purchase. Outside of the main plot, players can strive to uncover 100% of the clips - but absent a guide, this is an exercise in futility. The limits artificially placed on the search engine, from the limited results displayed to the minimalist design of the search history means completionists will spend their time fumbling about to find three-second clips of just four or five words.

[i]Her Story[/i] is an impressive reimagining of a lost gaming form. With a captivating mystery told by a convincing actress, players joining to view the story as it unfolds should be satisfied. The short runtime, low replay value, and frustrating limits affecting completionist play do hinder the experience, but especially when on sale this title is worth a watch. [i]Her Story[/i] gets a B.

[h1]Your Story[/h1]
If there's one thing [i]Her Story[/i] is especially good at doing, it's making you feel like you're deducing information on your own terms. Words and phrases shed light onto the walls of the branching cave system that is Her Story. Some tunnels connect and intersect, others leave you feeling totally lost. When a search term leads to a new plethora of information, it can be rather satisfying, but sooner or later, the keywords begin to dry up, and you're left with nothing more than your intuition and blind luck. And it's at this point that the cracks begin to show.

As a quick test, try to decipher my sentence in the text boxes below.

[spoiler]want[/spoiler][spoiler]you[/spoiler][spoiler]by[/spoiler][spoiler]recommendation[/spoiler][spoiler]If[/spoiler][spoiler]film[/spoiler][spoiler]out[/spoiler][spoiler]Noe[/spoiler][spoiler]a[/spoiler][spoiler]“Climax”[/spoiler][spoiler]check[/spoiler][spoiler]Gaspar[/spoiler] 

Once you’ve done that, check the box below for the answer.

[spoiler]If you want a film recommendation, check out “Climax” by Gaspar Noe.[/spoiler]

What you just did is, in essence the core gameplay of Her Story. You are given information, albeit out of sequence, and are required to string things back together on your own terms. Often times, only a single piece of the information will be the key information (in this example, the name of the film, “Climax”) and the rest of the pieces of information surrounding it act as waymarkers contextualising its meaning. This style of gameplay remains interesting until you hit a dead end, and you’re forced to take shots in the dark. If I had given you the same sentence, but lacking several key words, the solution could only be guessed, perhaps not even guessed at all based upon the missing information.

[b]BEWARE, HERE BE SPOILERS[/b]

The duration of the game is spent reviewing a database of recordings from the mid 90's of a lady in an interrogation room. The intrigue begins to amp up as she begins to talk about death, murder and her ‘reflection’. It soon becomes clear that all is not as it seems, and listening for names and keywords allows you to search the database to find more. The thing is, the database only allows you to view the first 5 results at a time, so blanket-term searching is usually ineffectual, and there exists the necessity to be specific.
Ironically, Her Story doesn't entertain the idea of giving you a fully fleshed-out story, and leaves you to fill in the gaps yourself. Though this is narratively cohesive, seeing as the woman [spoiler]women[/spoiler] we're watching is (by and large) actively trying to deceive and throw us off the scent. As we delve deeper, it becomes apparent just how orchestrated her life has been up until this point, and how she revels in the idea of blurring the lines between reality and fantasy.

The investigation ends up being rather surface level. I thought at one point there were going to be puzzles involving morse code, but the information that was tapped out had no real bearing upon the gameplay or mystery itself. It’s literally just browsing an archive, but with parameters holding you back from attaining all the information at once. It starts off pretty engaging, but only gets more frustrating and laborious as time goes on. What’s more BIG SPOILER HERE:[spoiler]the game doesn’t really have an ending, you’re simply offered the option to leave, and it’s left at that[/spoiler]. It’s irritating that I can’t express a lot of my qualms with this game for fear of ruining the experience for somebody who might have more fun with it than I did.

Her Story is zero fun to play alone. I tried to play through solo twice, but gave up at around an hour in both times. Playing it with a friend is much more satisfying, as one can take notes, and the other can dictate and type into the system. There’s more room for speculation between two people as well, which makes a playthrough more enjoyable. Even still, the experience didn’t end up being particularly satisfying. We managed to find everything in the database, and were still left with a feeling of “that’s it?”

To conclude, Her Story is a unique concept that starts as pretty fun and engaging, but begins to drag as time goes on. It’s very light on its puzzle elements, and could have been more if it had encoded more information for players to uncover.

4/10

108830496.review:
Overall:

A very original and thought provoking mystery game, with a fascinating, deep story and a brilliant performance by Viva Seifert more than making up for what it lacks in puzzles.

8.5/10

The good:

Starting with presentation, things are pretty simple. The player is looking at an old police desktop from the 90's, which has access to a database of FMV clips from the police interviews of a woman talking about her husband's murder. Most of the sounds you hear are diegetic, like mouse clicks, the flickering of the CRT monitor, and the occasional police siren. This combination of visuals and sound so grounded in reality really allow the player to become immersed in their role, trying to put the story together. This is very important, because the driving force behind the gameplay is the player's own curiosity.

The gameplay revolves around picking up clues and leads from the woman's interview clips to find new search terms, which will give access to more clips, and therefore more clues to help untangle the story. The acting and framing of the woman are very naturalistic, which further enhances the game's grounded "true crime" vibe, while the writing only seems naturalistic, hiding tons of subtext, repeated themes, and beautifully poetic moments beneath the surface. This forces the player to use not only their rationality, pattern seeking and information processing capabilities, but also their emotional intelligence, a skill not often put to the test by traditional murder mystery games. Her Story's open ended nature poses an interesting design problem: "If every clip is accessible from the start of the game, how does the developer control the story's pacing, so that the player doesn't stumble into the mystery's solution immediately?". The answer lies in the meticulous detail given to the information provided at every clip, with red herrings and dead ends scattered among the useful information, and a clever mechanic, where only the chronologically first 5 clips containing the search term are provided to the player. That way, the major spoilers are less likely to be encountered early, and even if they are, not enough context is provided in each one so that the story fully makes sense.

The meh:

As it has been made pretty clear by now, most of your time playing the game will revolve around watching videos of the woman talking. There are no puzzles, no test at the end, and no hint system. Those looking for standard adventure game gameplay will not find it here, and that may be a deal breaker for some. Also, there is no in-game notepad, which may have been useful for many players. Instead, the players can add their own user tags to clips, so they can be found easier. I didn't make use of this feature personally, as it seemed a bit too time consuming, but it may be useful for some. [spoiler] Also, the ending is pretty open ended and there are lingering questions concerning the characters' motives and trustworthiness. I loved that, but I know some will find it frustrating [/spoiler].

The bad:

The game also allows the player to save clips on a separate place called "user session", providing instant access for later reference. To my knowledge, it is impossible to delete clips from the user session, even when the player has already investigated everything in them. This caused me some frustration, and kept me from saving clips on the user session for most of my playthrough, because I didn't know whether they would be worth the clutter. Other parts of the UX could have been streamlined a bit to help those who want to view all 271 clips. There is no way to play all the clips in chronological order, or even access clips you've already seen without using the search bar. This only becomes an annoyance towards the end of the game, when you might want to find very specific, short clips that contain basically no relevant information, or even that many words at all. I resorted to a walkthrough for those, and that kinda killed the pacing of the story for me.

106916133.review:
Her Story is more of a proof of concept than a game - but it is a really cool experience. You're tasked with piecing together a story by searching for video clips on a database - all clips are from multiple interviews with the same actress, who recently had a loved one die under mysterious circumstances. You can only understand what's going on by searching for key words in her testimony - making for a non-linear narrative experience.

Some of the "gameplay" elements feel a little arbitrary - you can only watch videos by searching for key words, you can only see a certain number of results whenever you search, you don't know what questions are being asked, a few other things. It makes sense that these techniques would be used in order to provide some mystery to the player - it certainly makes discovering the story much more impactful than just watching the clips sequentially would have. But it can also feel like the "game" designation is a little tacked on. Really, this is all about the story (see game title), anything in here is to serve the narrative - regardless of player agency or how a video database would be designed in the real world.

I would like to see this kind of concept fleshed out in another game. One where I can make notes of things, and the game has more in-depth tracking of what I'm understanding about the story. More interactivity. The only thing this really tracks is if you've watched enough clips to understand the twist of the story. That's it. I had a few other "a-ha" moments in here that I wish I could have communicated in-game to influence the story. This could be great if it was expanded into a crime series, but instead of a cold-case, you are tasked with watching testimony for ongoing investigations. This concept mixed with a little Phoenix Wright.

Still, a unique experience, which blurs the line between video game and short film in an exciting and mind-bending way.

[b]TLDR[/b] If you accept it for what it is - an interactive movie with some game elements - Her Story will provide you a unique and gratifying experience. [18/20⭐, 12h🏅, 1/5💡]

[b]Context[/b] There’s a lot of opinions about whether Her Story is a game or not. My opinion is that it is not, it’s essentially an interactive movie, and I was only able to enjoy the experience once I accepted this fact.

[b]Writing[/b] You are essentially exploring a database of recorded police interviews, putting the pieces together regarding a murder case.  

[b]Aesthetics[/b] The aesthetics of a dated and limited computer interface fit perfectly in this context. The records are live action footage, with top level acting. 

[b]Gameplay[/b] However, the “game” doesn’t ever ask you to make a decision regarding the case. In fact, it never asks you for any feedback at all. [spoiler]This makes even more sense in the end when you realize who we’re playing as.[/spoiler] There are also no restrictions on the order you happen to access the entries. All this makes for a unique experience for each player.

There are no gameovers nor deaths, nor different chapters or levels. 

[b]Value[/b] Steam marks my playtime at 14h, which it not bad for something that is not even a game. Although I must admit I was starting to get frustrated searching for the last few entries. Achievements are related to finding hidden interactions with the database. There is a single progress slot. You can always revisit the logs. This is one of those games that is replayable just "for the experience".

[b]Playing status:[/b] 100% achievement
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (~9 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Her Story[/b] is an FMV game about a woman that is interviewed several times about a murder. You'll have to search for a keyword that will show lists of videos to watch in order to piece the whole story together.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Keywords and tags make it easy to find videos that you are looking for
- Piece your own story from the multiple recordings that are presented

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Those who have trouble reading non-linear stories might have a problem understanding it

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you like to theorize and watch an FMV game about murder, buy this game at a sale.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
The visual is split into two: a computer-like interface and a video where the interview took place. The computer looks like the one from the old XP operating system. There is a trash bin, notepad, and software where you can search and watch videos. It works similar to how computers usually work, so it shouldn't take long before you get used to it. The game also has a CRT filter turned on by default to make you feel like you are actually on the other side of the computer.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story is told in pieces. A lot of recordings of a woman's interview will be available to watch based on a series of keywords. Your job is to piece the story together to make out what actually happened. However, this can be a daunting task since some videos are useless to begin with. One-liner words about a woman asking for a complaint or spilling her cup will also be recorded and preserved, making it hard to find the ones that matter.

It's better to watch all videos chronologically. To be honest, I'm not good at reading non-linear stories, especially when I have to piece it together from a lot of non-correlative words. It took me a while to realize that there is a way to watch them chronologically, and once I do it, the game becomes more enjoyable. The one-liner sentences that look odd at first were starting to make sense, and it was easier for me to watch how the story unfolds.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1825285219

The game has an open ending story. The last few videos will tell you what happened, but whether the woman is telling the truth or not will be left up to you. There might still be some mysteries hidden beneath the woman's story too. Those who like to theorize will find themselves tinkering about what actually happened.

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
If you haven't noticed already, the game is focused on watching video clips. You have to use a keyword to find videos that have that exact word in them, allowing you to find more keywords and clues that you can use. You can only watch the first 5 videos from the search result though, so you must be more specific if you want to look at the others. Taking notes of important keywords will be vital throughout the game as a way to find more videos.

There is no hint or whatsoever in case you are stuck. You will be forced to guess for keywords if you run out of them, hoping that they will give you something. I found it to be annoying, especially since I didn't know what was going on with the story. A lot of facts were given to me when I wasn't sure whether they are relevant or not. It wasn't until I found out how to watch the videos in chronological order before I enjoyed the game to its fullest.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=493984475

There might be some "jumpscares" in the game. At some point, the screen will flicker, showing a reflection of someone's face on the screen. It's not scary, but it was enough for me to stop playing the game at night. Luckily, you can turn the CTR filter off, removing the "jumpscare" in the process.

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished the game in 2.6h. The difficult part of the game lies in finding the right keyword to find new videos, although you can bypass it if you know what you are doing. Besides, as I said before, the game was better to be watched in chronological order.

[b]Problems[/b]
I couldn't seem to trigger the ending even though I had watched all videos. It seems to be bugged since I found that [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/368370/discussions/0/357287935539036897/#c361798516952387924]some people[/url] were experiencing the same thing. Luckily, the solution that was provided in the same thread worked.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Her Story[/b] is different from other games. It's a game about murder, but you are not going to catch the murderer - everything related to the murder has already been resolved by the police. There are a lot of video clips to watch, and you only have to find the truth about what happened. How you perceive the story is up to you either. It's clearly not the common type of story to play, so if you are not up for these kinds of games, I suggest you stay out of it. Feel free to buy it at a sale if you are interested in it though - the game can be too short with the original price tag.

Her Story is a gritty mystery with unsettling characters who I'm very fond of!

The narrative is delivered through a fragmented series of interviews from a police investigation and it is essential to pay close attention to everything that is said. Careful interpretation of the dialogue is the only way to uncover the truth hidden within the stories that are told. The setting is grounded but the case is interwoven with the magic of fairytales, so a consideration of the make-believe is important for understanding the reality.

Her Story depends on player immersion more than the average narrative game does. The player has to want to keep searching and to think of increasingly creative search terms; the player has to figure out exactly what they're being told; the player has to piece everything together and decide when it's the end. It is more fitting and realistic for the game to have no real ending but, understandably, some people may be disappointed by the lack of conclusion. Personally, I enjoyed the unconventional gameplay and found it refreshing and satisfying.

Her Story is a story all about storytelling.

I had this game sitting in my Steam backlog for years, but never bothered to touch it until now. Now that I have, and all I can say is wow. What a phenomenal game.

Detective games have always wanted to put you in the shoes of the detective's experience as you solve a mystery, but there's often a disconnect between the player, the avatar, and the mystery itself. Her Story cuts out the avatar and places you in a position that immediately connects the mystery to you. As such, all the lazy inhibitions you may feel in a typical detective game are lifted as the mystery is now yours to contend with, and there's no on-rail narrative awaiting you. Your effort is your own. You are viewing footage of a particular woman's many interviews, but your only available resource to sift through the videos is an outdated computer interface. That and, of course, your own level of curiosity. Through the power of blanket discovery do you get wrapped up in what this game's narrative has to offer. It'll take hold of you as you piece together a disjointed story into something cohesive - and all your work into it will feel necessary. Truly a one of a kind type of game and I am so glad I finally played it.

As an emotional experience, this might be the closest a game has gotten to a good book or movie for me. At the risk of coming off as an elitist of medium, I just think games are better at systems than stories, and when they do try to tell stories they're just worse because they don't lean so hard on your imagination (books) or the massive bandwidth of human empathy (everything with human faces in it). So, sure, this is a glorified movie, but the light touch of game is entirely harmonious and effective.

Is the sense of accomplishment in solving the mystery illusory? Kind of, but I don't think that matters; I don't think that's the point. What it's really serving is a look into her world, and you get to choose what you learn about first, and piece it together yourself as you go along. That's self-directed learning, which is always satisfying, and your path to understanding feels special because you chose each step. But whichever path you take, you learn about her life and her world and her trauma and her hopes and her fears. It's a dense expositional dump about one person's experience of the world, and offers a glimpse so vivid it is barely matched by heavyweights of character-first storytelling.

Great game/movie/thing.

93049768.review:
This is an FMV game in which you watch a series of video clips (more than 200 in total if you want to see all of them) and piece together what happened in a murder case.

The clips are entirely of police tapes of a woman being interviewed.  In order to locate them, you have to type in search words or terms and see what comes up on the results.  You don't have to watch all the clips or formally link together the videos to make deductions.  How far you progress into the game is entirely up to you.  There is no "ending" as such.  Your motivation to continue depends entirely on whether you want to learn more about the story - or not.  It is very unconventional gameplay for a mystery game, but I like the fact that something different is being done.

What makes this story very clever for me is the way in which people's view on the story tends to fall into one of two different interpretations of the events.  I must confess that my view falls in what appears to be the minority view out of the two.  To say anything about either interpretation would ruin the enjoyment of the game, so please forgive me for sounding cryptic in this review.  I couldn't even say what film springs to mind when I think of the story, suffice to say there is a very famous one and I'm surprised to find no reference to it in any of the discussion forums.

The setting for the game is in the 1990s.  And I think that's deliberate so that mobile phones do not have to be included.  Had mobiles have featured in the story, the police (and in turn, the player) would have been able to reach a conclusion to the crime more easily.  The game is carefully crafted so that more than one theory has at least some degree of plausibility, in order to keep you guessing.  And it works - the discussions about the game prove that.  People who have played the game are still reading the views of others and discussing the events long after the game is over and seeing all the video clips.  In most games, the post-play discussion is usually around certain plot points, potential sequels and so on - not the main story itself.

You never get to hear the questions being asked by the police.  There are also no case notes to guide you.  While you may form your interpretation of events early on, the police who investigated the case might not necessarily have had the same view.  That's a clever move on the part of the developers, in my view.

Viva Seifert's excellent performance as the suspect being interviewed by the police is what this game's success largely hinges on.  Credit must be given where it is most certainly due because the role she's playing is a very challenging one to pull off.  And that is true, regardless of which interpretation of the events you believe to be true.  I'm surprised this actress has a very limited filmography.  I would like to see her in more games and in some films too.

I agree with the reviewer who pointed out that the database restriction to five results for a given search term is rather implausible.  But it's a minor flaw, and certainly doesn't harm enjoyment of the game.

Overall, what we have here is an unconventional but highly interesting game.  It is very different from the usual detective FMV games such as Contradiction - Spot the Liar and The Shapeshifting Detective, for example.  The nearest comparison is The Infectious Madness of Doctor Dekker, but without the increasingly confusing stories told by the different characters.  Fans of that game will probably like this one too.
