Her Story follows you playing an investigator that has been sent to review evidence in the form of a series of FMV interviews with a British woman, Hannah, throughout 1994, which was used to convict her of murdering her husband Simon. The system for finding these consists of entering in keyword(s) that are spoken in the dialogue of the clips into a database, which will return matching videos; but only display the first five of them to watch. Firstly, I enjoyed this system of puzzle game-like storytelling, as it required some scrutiny of dialogue and knowledge of narrative to find footage given what you have already seen. I also thought the idea of telling a story through police interrogations was great, and the game goes beyond the crime itself to explore the character’s life and background. And since these are told in an inherently nonlinear fashion, it is up to the player to understand what happened. Additionally, after some time watching, it will become clear there is more here to find out than a simple “whodunnit?”, with Hannah’s life holding a big secret that could explain the crime.
However, having played Return of the Obra Dinn around a year ago, which similarly tasks the player with discovering disjointed evidence and making sense out of it, I was quite disappointed by the game’s conclusion. I thought, for example, that you might need to arrange the evidence in order using cues from the footage, or explain what happened at the crime using the evidence you found to make a case for innocence. But your knowledge of the game’s events is never actually put to the test by the end, nor are you incentivized to actually collect all of the footage past the halfway point save for curiosity’s sake. Instead, the game ends almost immediately once you are done searching for evidence, with only a final twist that has little impact since there is no time given to acknowledge it. Additionally, the search method for finding videos can quickly give way to blind guessing once you have collected the majority of them; the game even acknowledges this hindrance by making you aware of a command to pull up a random clip from the database once you have beaten the game.
So while I would certainly strongly recommend this game on the merits of its storytelling methods and presentation, especially considering its low price, I was nonetheless let down by its sudden conclusion and turn to brute-force guessing.

84430204.review:
This game is brilliant. A very creative addition to the detective game genre and one I hope has impact on future developers. 

The main shortcoming of detective games is that it's hard to give players the freedom to make their own choices and deductions without giving them the answer. For example, if there are three dialogue choices for an answer, one of them might give the player a deduction that they didn't come to themselves until prompted to the idea by the game. It goes without saying that that is not the best way to design a detective game.

Her Story is a game about a murder mystery where you have to watch interviews to gather evidence to make your deductions. However, they aren't in order. They are put in a database where, if you enter a term that appears in the video, you may find the first five videos with that term. The player makes their own deductions, jots down notes, useful terms, similar motifs, and creates their own idea on the story. Some of these are pointless or red herrings but some of them are supported and appear frequently. 
Ultimately, this ends up creating a very personal narrative to the game's story. Sometimes, players are given a straight line of thought to a conclusion and other times they need to make their own inferences.

There are two very very high points for this game in that regard.
- The player has to type keywords in the search bar to search for results, which allows the players a lot of creative freedom to make their own deductions on the truth of the story.
- The player can choose to end the game when they are satisfied with the conclusion of the story. Pretty much, after watching some of the videos, the player receives a call asking them if they are satisfied with the conclusion they've gathered.

Let's talk about the first one. It sounds like a really simple mechanic but it is a great way to give players feedback from their own deductions. From the videos that do show up, the player is given a fair idea on the legitmacy of their conclusion, without the game explicitly stating so.

The second one doesn't have much to do with the detective game genre specifically but it's a much larger commentary on the way we engage with video games. 
When do you "finish" or "beat" a game? Is it when you beat the final boss? Perhaps, get the true ending? Or maybe, you need to 100% it?
For some games, there's a clear answer. You beat "Super Mario Bros." when you kill Bowser in the final castle. However, for a mystery, when do you exactly finish? 
There is no part of "Her Story" where the game explicitly says, "Congratulations, you've solved the mystery". You, the player, have to decide when you are satisfied with the conlcusions that you have made and what you've gathered from it and that struck me as really beautiful.

I'm sure you may have heard from Mark Brown but there's this great post on the "Community" tab that asks about the length of the game. To which it was replied, it ends when you're satisfied with what you've seen and you have the answers you need. Then the OP replied, "How will I know when I'm satisfied?".
That really showed me how people rely on traditional structure and defined conclusions of video games for their enjoyment and how creatively limiting the medium can be because of it.

This is a game with a great idea and a little bit of poor user experience (which can be easily fixed by adding a few small improvements). The general idea of the game is to learn the whole story by revealing parts of the videos from the database (by querying the key worlds). This is quite a nice approach but things below make the whole game less fun:

1. The introduction to the game is not very expanded. I was missing at the beginning description of the goal of the game - what do I want to do and why. I was a little bit confused at the beginning because of this.

2. There is not an easy way of ordering videos that you find and watching them in that order. When you find a clip you can add it to a clipboard called "session". This is the biggest disadvantage of the game, as at some point it changes the way how you play it from revealing the story by watching videos to querying dictionary worlds randomly to find the missing videos. Because of this issue, I lost the fun of playing this game.

3. There is no clear indication from which bigger video you miss the clip. There is a program in a game that shows you which part of the memory is still missing. But it is not easy to translate this to the video level, the only way to do it is to order everything manually and cont by yourself.

As you can see this is a promising game, that can be very fun when just a few things get fixed. But unfortunately, right now it loses a lot because of the design.

81548990.review:
This game is definitely one of a kind. It's original in it's construction and the gameplay is unique.
It manages to grab your attention from the very beginning and your attitude transitions from " Well, ok, let's try this one out. I bought it on sale, it was cheap, let's give it a shot " to " Well, well, well, this is actually pretty good!" At least in the first hour or two.
Here you are some kind of a police officer, maybe a detective. You're sitting in from of a CRT monitor, you log in and you're told to take a look at an interview footage, showing a woman undergoing questioning, in regards to her husband's dissapearance. Her being the prime suspect in the case.
The game throws you into a deep water right away and it doesn't show you the ropes, nor does it explain, what your role is in all of this. Do you have to solve the mystery? Do you have to point, who's guilty here?
You start with 4 short video footages and one word visible in the search browser " MURDER ". That's your starting package. From now on you're on your own.
You progress through the game by watching those clips, making notes, on what's being said and you're then using the search browser, looking for more clips and clues, by using key words. Now this is a neat idea, as long as the GUI is made user friendly enough, to facilitate this.
See, the problem is, for any word, you can see a maximum of 5 clips at the same time, so if a certain word brings you 30 results, you're missing the other 25 and you have to find a more detailed phrase, to find the other ones. Now, this is not a terrible idea, but at some stage, you find yourself typing in every possible word from each of the clips and with each finding, the number of video footages increases. 
 Ok, you can save each clip for future reference and each of those footages is moved to the tab at the bottom, but the most frustrating part I think, is that there's no efficient way to browse through those clips. There's no way to sort them in chronological order, apart from dragging and dropping from one end of the tab to another. So when you have saved 200 clips, you can't just choose " interviews from 18,06,1994 sorted from earliest to last ". No, you have to pick each and every one of them manually and you also have to click on every one of them and read the date and time of those and then manually place them side by side, which feels like a massive chore. 
It basically extends the time it takes to complete the game 3 times. I actually felt, like I was at work, inputting data into excel 8 hours a day. At some stage I couldn't be bothered anymore, because it was taking sooo much time, that it was just not worth it and game breaking at that.

Also it's very possible, that one of your search words will forward you to the last interview and you will watch a spoiler and you will know, what has actually happened, without even being half way through your investigation. If you know how it ended, will you keep investigating, what lead to this? 
Also, I quickly realised, I'm just an observer here. I don't take any active part in the investigation. All I'm doing is, I'm trying to find pieces of the puzzle, put them together and just watch, what happened. I'm not a guy trying to figure this out myself and then point a finger at someone, or decide, if she's guilty, or not.
This game feels like " Dear Esther " told in a more chaotic way.

So while the game is one of a kind and it did entertain me in the first 2 hours, it ended up frustrating me and the above issues have ultimately put me off in the end. I know how it ended, I know what her problem is, but I didn't feel like trying to sort this all out, to watch it from beginning to the end, nor did the game want me to.

So it's a hand down and a 6 /10 for me. A lot of promise,  but not backed up with a user friendly interface and solid gameplay construction.

An impressively engaging taking on the "FMV" genre, [i]Her Story[/i] puts the player in an  investigative role, exploring a fictional police database of clips cut from interviews with a female mrder suspect - the catch being that your only means of querying the database is using the words spoken in each short clip (which are often only a few seconds long). There's clearly been a lot of work put into that script all the same, to ensure that there are just enough strings to tug on and make further progress, without becoming either too straightforward or too obscure - and the game smartly leaves you to draw your own conclusions about some of the fine detail.

79136231.review:
Her Story is a short and sweet experiment in storytelling. The premise of learning about a mystery story by looking it up with keywords is such a strong departure from the usual narrative, while at the same time oddly familiar to anyone that has had to do research via search engine. I am smitten by this premise.

It is, however, short, and the slightest bit rough around the edges. The radical nonlinearity in presentation of what is otherwise a linear story is not without its drawbacks: the longer the story is, the harder it is to design it to have enough impact regardless of which order is used to experience it. I feel like a couple of plot elements didn't land perfectly because forging onward unbothered will clear them up later regardless. I have a couple of other smaller qualms, too: for one, there really isn't a way to prevent the player from guessing ahead instead of making smart inferences, which I think could probably be more effectively hidden; for another, some of the story bytes that are required for full linearity, are too short to be reasonably accessed in the specific choice of format, of queries to a database of interrogation responses that are divorced from their prompting questions.

None of that is to say the acting isn't up to par (it is) or the story is bad (I loved it), but this lack of polish does put a slight damper on what is otherwise a standout video game narrative with the courage to push its medium in little-explored direction. But this is also where the short length of the game proves to be a strength instead of a weakness: it's too short for these issues to become proper nuisances, so the experiment retains its good-natured novelty throughout.

76161804.review:
[h1][b]Dreadful wind and rain[/b][/h1]

[h1][b]Full review at [url=https://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=314]GameDragons.Net[/url][/b][/h1]

[b]Presentation[/b]
Her Story is a unique game that's pretty complicated to fully explain without looking at video footage of it in action, but due to its limited run time and heavy focus on story anything that you might show could be considered a spoiler, so it's a hard job to recommend this game on its premise alone, but just because it's such a unique experience I'll try my best to peek your interest without stripping you of the main surprise, which is the story. The reason Her Story is such a different game is because it's barely a game at all, as a matter of fact most people described it as an interactive movie, but I feel like that's also an inaccurate description of what this game is. There's about 2 hours of video footage, but it's not a movie that you're watching from the beginning to the end, instead that content is sliced into smaller videos, some only a few seconds long, while others spanning a few minutes. Using a search engine built into the game you can look up words or small phrases and based on subtitles the game will return all videos that contain those words, regardless of length. Because of this each player will uncover videos in a different order, but regardless of what that order is you will still reach that one moment when you figure out what the catch of the story is and depending on which video you watch first that impact may differ, but the plot twist is what you are here for and regardless of the video that clicks for you, the realization of what you're looking at will still be a surprise no matter what.

As for the premise of the game all you need to know is that you are investigating the murder of Simon Smith by looking at interviews with his wife Hannah starting with the moment after his disappearance all the way to the point when his body was found. As those videos are dated it is up to you to put the events in order and figure out the mystery of what happened based on the footage you're watching and even though some videos are just small talk with the interviewer, some of them provide valuable information about what happened, so paying attention to what Hannah is saying in each scene is important not only to get an idea of what happened to Simon, but also to pick your words carefully for the next search to maximize the results of finding more useful footage. Even though plenty of characters are mentioned, you are only looking at Hannah's interviews, so you must deduce each character's role in the story and the murder based on what she says about each one of them. If you like police or investigation type games, Her Story will most likely satisfy you from a plot perspective as there is one major plot twist somewhere at the middle point depending on when you figure it out and then another big one at the end, which I honestly didn't see coming at all.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
From a gameplay perspective the search engine mechanic makes up most of the game, as the whole point is accessing the entire video database by searching for the right words, so you have to listen to anything Hannah says in one video and then take some keywords out of what she said in order to look them up and get more context on that topic, whether it's an event, character name or a more general word like "murder". To prevent you from exploiting the system by searching for common words, each search inquiry only returns 5 results even if there are more videos containing that word, but the game is structured in such a way that looking up any specific thing that Hannah mentioned will usually point you to another video that will repeat the cycle. Figuring out which words to search for isn't hard either, as you can quite easily work out what you should be looking for next if you pay attention to the interviews. Once you've seen around 75% of the footage you can choose to either continue or end the game which will reveal the final plot twist, but even if you know what the plot twist is without watching everything, there are some interesting and sometimes even funny conversations hidden inside more hard to find videos, so watching everything is highly encouraged if you want to get the full picture.

Even though you are on a computer at all times, aside from searching for the next set of videos there isn't a lot to do, there are only a few notepads left on the desktop with some basic instructions about the game and a minigame called Mirror Game which you can play for as long as you like, but aside from that the main story is all there is, however considering the type of game this is, it doesn't really require anything else in order to achieve what it sets out to do, as the plot twists in the story do that all by themselves. Her Story isn't much of a game, but it's an amazing and certainly unique experience that you should definitely try out if you like mystery and investigation simply because the conclusion here will probably surprise you no matter what.

[b]Graphics[/b]
Since the game takes place in 1994, all the video footage was made to look like it came out of that era, so you have CRT display lines that were common in footage from that period and also a low resolution effect to the videos, on top of the fact that you are looking at a CRT monitor at all times, but all of that is done for the sake of immersion and it never bothered me one bit because visuals aren't the main focus of the game here. The PC interface is also made to resemble Windows 95, but despite that the UI theme has a 90s police appeal more than a common UI from 1994.

[b]Audio[/b]
One of the main reasons the story has such a big impact is because of Viva Seifert who plays the role of Hannah and her exceptional acting skills, and even thought I'd like to expand on that phrase more, it would be impossible for me to do so without going into spoiler territory, so you're just gonna have to trust me on this one. There are some tunes integrated into some videos, but it's not the soundtrack of the game that you're hearing, but instead Hannah singing and playing the guitar. On the topic of audio effects all there is to talk about is the PC interface, which is basic, but considering it's made to resemble the early version of Windows, it is justified.

[b]Extras[/b]
It takes around 3 hours to complete the entire game and there's only one ending so replayablity is not a feature here; aside from that the only thing that could be counted as an extra is the Mirror Game which gets boring after 3 rounds in the bast case scenario, but considering the main focus on the story and the experience as a whole here, extras aren't really necessary.

[b]Verdict[/b]
If you are looking for something unique with a great plot twist and don't mind the almost non-existant gameplay, Her Story might be something for you, especially if mystery and investigation are also topics of interest to you. Since the game is only 3 hours long you can finish this easily in one session, so the next time you're searching for a movie to spend the night with, consider Her Story as a viable option because after all, it is just an out of order movie with a great story and shocking plot twists.

[h1]CUANDO EL ESPEJO TE DEVUELVE LA MIRADA...[/H1]

Mas que un juego, Her Story es un intento por ofrecer una experiencia diferente e innovadora al jugador aprovechando el tímido resurgimiento de los juegos FMV por un lado y las bondades de la industria indie actual que permite hacer videojuegos con poco medios y muy poca inversión.

Aunque solo se por el hecho de intentar innovar el juego ya resulta lo suficientemente interesante y llamativo como para despertar el interés a más de uno, y de ahí la fama y los premios que ha cosechado. 

El planteamiento de Her Story es bien sencillo a la par que original. Se ha cometido un crimen y tendremos que averiguar que ha pasado desentrañando la trama a través de los vídeos de los interrogatorios que la policía hace a una única persona, solo hay un actriz en todo el juego, buscando palabras claves en sus declaraciones que nos lleven a otros vídeos para ir uniendo las piezas. 

Y así de sencillo.

Una actriz, una historia y buscar palabras que nos lleven a las otras partes de los interrogatorios. 

De lo que viene a ser un fragmento de la jugabilidad presente en muchas aventuras gráficas, al fin y al cabo eso de buscar palabras claves en un texto o conversación no es nada nuevo, se hace un juego completo única y exclusivamente con esa premisa .

La originalidad y la innovación viene por el formato en el que se ha decidido hacer el juego. Una única actriz, bastante buena por cierto, en formato FMV y con una historia rota en mil pedazos que debemos ir construyendo. 

Un planteamiento que ciertamente funciona... pero como mera curiosidad, me temo. 

En efecto, una vez pasados los primeros momentos del juego, cuando se evapora la efervescencia, resulta
más que evidente que estamos ante un juego con una jugabilidad muy sencilla y limitada que a pesar de haberse sabido rodear del artificio necesario y haber sabido venderse bien... es muy poco lo que ofrece y por eso resulta difícil ver el juego como algo más que una de las curiosidades que a veces nos trae la esfera indie.

Interesante como curiosidad, simpático como excusa para pasar unas pocas horas jugando a una propuesta diferente... pero escaso y limitado como para que uno se plantee algo más profundo y trascendente. 

Para un juego ocasional de corta duración, pues si. Para juegos más largos o crear un subgénero, pues no. 

Juego recomendable para los más curiosos y hambrientos de planteamientos diferentes. También para los más completistas y amantes de las aventuras gráficas en todas sus vertientes. 

Abstenerse aquellos sin interés en explorar la esfera indie o los que no tengan ganas de que le estén contando mandangas. 


6/10.

TL;DR Utterly unique and worth experiencing, however the gameplay is bad and story is only ok. 

Her Story is a unique game where you watch interview footage of a woman who has been involved with a murder. The trick is you can only watch short little clips of the interview by searching words said during the clip. 

The only reason I recommend this game is because it is an utterly unique and creative premise; currently you are unlikely to find anything quite like it. It is so interesting to watch a mystery unfold through these short clips and you stumble on them in such a unique way. There also has clearly been some thought put into how you discover clips, so there are actually some clever twists built in.

Story/mystery is ok. It is compelling, and there some good reveals, but overall be prepared for some melodrama and a story that is a bit over the top (but I think most mystery games tend to be over the top, so while I may not be a fan this may not actually be a point against it). The actress is pretty good, believable enough, but some of her acting quirks begin to show because you spend so much time starring at her.

EDIT: The analysis of the story runs very deep. If you want to get lost in a rabbit hole of analysis and theories, where meaning is wrung out of every word, this may be the game for you. You may finish the game in 4ish hours but you can easily spend dozens of hours going over it. 

The gameplay is unfortunately atrocious. It was an artistic decision to make the game hard to use (the creator has openly responded to requests to change it) and in my opinion that is a real shame. If you save a clip by adding it to your "user session" you cannot remove it. Rearranging clips is a nightmare. Everything you searched is just added to a list with no way of navigating it. Adding user tags is more harmful than useful. Worst of all, clicking "Delete Session Data" doesn't delete the user session as you might think, it deletes your game. I fell for that like so many others. It is just plain bad design, whether it is intentional or not. This makes it all but impossible to sort the clips in chronological order. Do yourself a favor, ignore "user session" and just find as many clips as you can, then when you believe you have found 80 to 90 percent of them, just watch the entire thing chronologically on youtube. It is NOT worth your time to sort it in game.

There is also no real resolution either. At some point you have an idea of what happened but you'll never get a conclusive answer or ending. Ambiguous endings can be good, but I think it doesn't serve mysteries terribly well. 

The bottom line is, I would LOVE to see another game like this but with better gameplay design. But I recommend Her Story despite its faults.

You can search for a word and if one of the ~270 video clips in the game includes that word, it will be included in a list. You can access the top 5 entries in that list. You can watch those clips. [i]Her Story[/i] is an FMV title that plays as a mystery story.  [i]Her Story[/i] is unique among the FMV class of games in that its story is not a linear progression; it is a series of clips presented in whichever order the player finds them.  To find clips, the play enters a keyword or collection of keywords, much like searching in an Internet search bar.  All clips are of a woman being interviewed by the police over several days.

Most FMV games play as a linear story with some elements of choice.  [i]Her Story[/i]'s method of storytelling is unique and creates a narrative experience unlike any other.  The story is not placed in front of the player; the player searches for the story.  Driven by their own curiosity, the player pieces the story together until they are satisfied.  This experience simply would not be possible in a simple movie or a traditional game.  It can only really be told in the medium [i]Her Story[/i] uses.  This game demands the player's interest and rewards their curiosity with an intriguing tale.

[i]Her Story[/i] is not for everyone.  There is no action.  There is no gore, no bullets, no zombies.  There are no flashy graphics or powerful soundtrack.  It is only the player and the woman.  It is all about her story.  The story is fun and interesting, but it is not an epic tale.  [i]Her Story[/i] will not make the player say "Wow!"  It will make the player give a fascinated declaration of "Huh!"  For those willing to let their own interest drive their experience in the story, [i]Her Story[/i] will surely be a novel experience.

Well, it's not for everyone and it sucks that people hype its storytelling so much but forget to mention that it's not really a game, but more like an open-ended investigative archiving simulator. 

Knowing the premise for the story and that a lot of people think this game is brilliant (the keyword being game), I was expecting some sort of progress leading to a genuine resolution. What Her Story actually is, however, is a collection of old tapes regarding a murder case. I asked a friend who played it if there was anything to it other than watching those tapes, if I was working towards something, if I were somehow helping the investigation or what, but nope.

These tapes are archived footage from what seems to be many years prior to them becoming available in the game's system. You're not even asked to archive them properly, to make the timeline easier to go through. You're just given them and that's the whole plot. What the game wants the meta plot to be is piecing together the story behind the murder for... really, no reason other than understanding it for your own sake.

It's fine if you just want a good story told in a unique way but as a game, I was expecting a bit more besides the tapes for the sake of it. Having them spread out is also too much of a gimmick imo. It'd be far more interesting to me if we had access to other documents and if the tapes weren't so disjointed, so that the investigative aspect actually feels like an investigation instead of watching the tapes for the sake of it. But to each their own.

VERY tempting at 90% off (got it at the summer sale 2020) but not even that price tag made me feel like I got my money's worth after I found out that there's not actually any objective at all besides watching the tapes and figuring out the story by yourself and that's really all there is to it. All are part of a series of interviews where a woman is questioned about the circumstances of his husband's death. [i]Never[/i] has a game left me so overwhelmed. Many great works of literature, music and science have certainly touched my heart, but a video game?

At first glance, [i]Her Story[/i] is an archive of videos of a woman being the suspect in a 90s murder case. But what at first seems to be a usual murder mystery eventually turns out to be a psychograph of that very woman. We get to know her viewpoint and her tale video by video. Every piece of knowledge is evidence for the slick detective within you who then begins searching conspicuous terms in the data base. Those terms will lead you either to dead ends or anecdotes and other clues. One might think that could lead 'pranksters' to finding the plot turn in the story very early. However, being able to see only the first 5 videos makes sure that the story unfolds one piece at at a time. Nevertheless you are completely free in whatever term you type in. That is why [i]Her Story[/i] is an individual experience, you experience it [i]your[/i] way. It is very rewarding to feel the nudges and at the same time know that you found the next clue by yourself. With enough pieces of [i]Her Story[/i] you will have many 'aha moments'. I myself had two of those and they left me speechless. I was lead very gently to the point that I could figure out the two most important questions by myself. I was so fascinated by this game that I searched for everything I could get, ranging from interviews over blog posts up to information about the one exceptional musical moment in the game. The actress did an amazing job and is perfect for the role. Well-made video games with convincing stories, some with great design and music, can be considered art. I am sure about that. The handful of little clips featuring her saying a specific word to make sure the Good Stuff is at least one clip out of reach at the beginning of the game. 

As a game selling itself 99% on story it could've done with a pass or two from a not-dude writer. There are occasional moments that veer into Game of Thrones-ian "dude trying to write complex women" territory (including, funnily enough, an incestual story that comes out of nowhere for little reason beyond shock value). It's not necessarily bad writing during those moments, but it definitely could've been something greater had it another hand on the ball.

Seifert's performance can seem stilted depending on which rabbit holes you fall down early on in your investigation. There's Plot Reasons behind that which lead to a masterful execution of her final interview that had me re-watching clips for enjoyment later in my investigation. 

The gameplay gimmick is cool, I always love a game that gets me taking physical notes in a fun way. The meta-story that suddenly erupts and then disappears adds some extra spice right around the time I found myself flagging and losing a sense of direction. 68411189.review:
Her stories

Her story is exactly that - her story. A woman telling a story to camera. Or stories. When it comes to the title, the game has more layers than one. 

It’s been called a game and an interactive film, but it’s really neither, because it has no gaming elements or interaction between the player and the movie. I would call it a movie puzzle or a movie. The mechanics are simple, the “player” gets 271 videos of a woman questioned about a murder case. The player then has to guess the right words to find the clips from the archive to build the full story.

The writer and director Sam Barlow uses the same mechanic later in “Telling Lies”. I started with the latter and watched both in almost one after another. What seemed innovative and original to me in the first jigsaw, started to feel repetitive and unnecessary in the second.  In Her story the plot was revealed fairly soon and finding the lost parts after that just wasn’t motivating.

The problem of the game is there’s not enough game. Shattering the movie to almost three hundred pieces and showing them in almost random order is a way of telling the story, not a game.  Is this even the right method? Does splitting the timeline add to the experience?

I know the comparison is as unfair as unfair goes, but lets take a look at Tarantino’s Pulp fiction. The movie has an unchronological timeline. Just like in Her story, the spectator puts pieces of the story together in his head while watching the movie, or after it, but the order is not random, far from it. Every scene is carefully placed to create exactly the revelations and the twists the director/ writer Tarantino wants them to. The movie is a movie jigsaw in form of a movie. Nobody calls it a game. Even if the clips were shown in random order, the movie would still not be a game. If the clips were shown in correct order, the movie would still be great, but would definitely lose some of it’s appeal. In Pulp fiction breaking the timeline adds to the experience and is an essential part of it.

In her story splitting the movie into a pool of clips is justified for one reason and it’s not necessarily flattering. The story would not work without this. When stripped down to the bone, the script is somewhat flat. If the clips were stitched to one movie, it would not be great, just a woman talking. It has one major hook that has been seen before and the clips leave very little room for deduction. Making realizations is a holy privilege of the spectator and should never be compromised. The puzzle brings this into the game, but is not enough to carry it through all the clips.

Unfortunately even the core mechanic can turn against itself. The spectator can stumble upon wrong clips and reveal the main twist very early. This will severely damage the experience, almost destroy it completely. It's like the director telling you what will happen before you get to watch the movie. In conclusion, Her story relies too much on an innovative game mechanic to cover up the shortcomings of the script. 

I would still recommend Her story. Everyone should try out movie jigsaw at least once. It’s a different experience to games or movies or any other way of telling a story. That is Barlow's true merit. Barlow’s second work Telling Lies is better in many aspects and if you’re planning to see just one, I would skip straight to that.

As for Barlow and the future, I would recommend him bringing more game into his games. What was innovative is becoming repetitive. He’s shown he has a gift of telling stories and courage to stray from known paths. He can be a groundbreaker. I'm Looking forward to it.

I give the game 7.5/10

Her Story is praised as innovative only because of its many contrivances. I think it's a decent game, but overall I wouldn't recommend buying it at the current asking price.

The gameplay and story are interwoven exceptionally, but that doesn't keep the story from falling short. Viva Seifert's performance is mostly compelling, but some of the dialogue is unnatural. One of my main gripes with the game with the game is the premise itself; I don't understand why you would tell a story like this unless your goal is to create a false sense of uniqueness or choice for the player.

Unearthing the first 60% or so of the database was enjoyable and easy. After that, it got frustrating. This is a problem inherent to the game's construction; it's either too easy or too difficult to progress. The fact that the story is non-linear does not help with this problem. It got frustrating because it turns out all I was missing were little clips that had essentially no bearing on the narrative. Especially frustrating were [spoiler] lie detector videos that are probably the biggest storytelling cop-out I've ever seen in a piece of media. The worst acting in the entire piece is also present here, which I believe essentially confirms my suspicion that there is no meat at all behind the polygraph interview. From then on, she and Hannah shared one life.  They would take turns pretending to be Hannah, they would share food, time with friends / family, classes, social life, dates, etc. They kept their days very exacting by writing diaries about exactly what they had said and done all day. All that changed at 17 when Hannah met Simon and fell in love.  Hannah broke the "rules" she and Eve had for each other because she 1. wouldn't share Simon with Eve and 2. became pregnant by Simon.  She and Simon got married, left Eve alone in her parent's attic and went to live with Simon's parents, Eleanor and Doug.  This was 1984. Things turned poorly for Hannah quickly - she miscarried at 8 months and became infertile.  Shortly after that, her parents were found dead with flu-like symptoms that were later revealed to be caused by poisoning from death cap mushrooms.  Since her dad was a mushroom expert, he should've known better than to eat them (and so it's hinted that Eve may have killed her bio parents to get Hannah to move home).  Hannah inherits her dead parent's house and moves back in with Simon.  Eve moves out to her own flat and works odd jobs under the table (singing in bars, mostly) to get by. She gets an apple / snake tattoo to commemorate the event.  One night by chance (or perhaps she intended to do this out of jealousy of Hannah's life and romance), Simon sees her at the bar.  He's struck by how identical she is to his wife.  He starts an affair with Eve and even fucks her in his marital bed.  Eve becomes pregnant.  Eve informs Hannah that she's pregnant and Hannah wants to give up their double life and tell Simon that his wife has a sister.  Eve tells her not to, though.  On her birthday, Simon gifts Hannah a unique mirror he hand made for her.  Later in that day, Eve and Hannah have a fight that turns physical since Hannah realizes Eve had an affair with Simon behind her back.  Eve hits Hannah and bruises her face. ★☆☆☆☆ Terrible!

[h1]Investigation[/h1]

A FMV “video game”, "Her Story" is really nothing more than a movie with a 90's interface. This pretty much points to the primary flaw in Her Story, as the actual story being told by the videos is best viewed sequentially, but the interface of the game makes it so that viewing the videos sequentially is extremely unlikely.

Hannah is the main character of Her Story, and indeed, the only one who shows up in the videos. The central conceit of the game is that Hannah was a murder suspect in 1994. The protagonist is going through an old police database, wherein the videos are sorted by keywords in their transcripts. This sounds like a clever idea, but in practice, it doesn’t really work very well at all, beyond being very confusing, it suffers from the fact that it is entirely possible to search for the wrong keyword and end up stumbling across the game’s central twist five minutes in.

Unsurprisingly, I did exactly this by simply searching for the most innocuous of the names I had come across first (for the record, it was the name of one of Hannah’s childhood friends). This resulted in me happening across a video which spoiled the game’s central plot twist, and consequently I spent the rest of the game trying to piece together everything else in the hopes of finding another twist, and then failing to find one.

The result of the search interface is that you are likely to watch lots of garbage scenes, with odd scenes which are really important thrown in between them. Some of the videos are nothing more than Hannah saying “no”, while others are minute-long monologues explaining crucial plot or character details.

Worst of all, if you actually watch the videos in order, they follow the standard variances of a plot. The rise and fall of action as the police officers piece things together before Hannah finally explains exactly what is going on in the final interview. As a movie, it makes sense.

But as a video game, it makes no sense at all.

It has other flaws as well – as a murder mystery game, one would think that little details would be pretty important, but as it turns out, the people who made the videos didn’t actually pay much attention to time constraints. On many occaisions, something happens – such as a character changing clothing, or taking a ponygraph – which ignores the necessary setup time, with the videos happening too close together in time. At first, I had assumed that these little mistakes was related to the plot twist, but eventually I realized it was simple laziness on the part of the game creators.

If the plot was actually viewed in order, it might be passable, though the awkward interface of the game still would make it annoying. And if parts had been locked off until you had figured some stuff out, it might have worked. But as it is, the thing is kind of a mess, and while the central idea wasn’t a bad one, the UI and erratic pacing as a result of it being made into a “game” (which it really isn’t any more than searching for stuff on YouTube is a “game”) makes it hard to really get into it properly. It is possible to spoil the entire plot of the game within five minutes, and a lot of the videos end up feeling a lot like filler, especially when viewed out of context.

Her Story is one of the rare examples of a game with a bold and unusual premise which it executes to perfection. It doesn't bend the rules, it doesn't cheat: it's just you, the videos, and your ability to navigate through them while piecing the story together on your own terms.

Some will dislike the lack of finality in the game, but I think it's one of its strongest elements. For me, the game didn't end when I'd seen the ~80% of the videos I needed to feel like I had a strong grasp on the story; it didn't end when I'd seen every video either, something the game helps you to do once you've told it you're done. I was up late into the night reading through forum threads and comments pages on reviews piecing together other people's interpretations of the story to see how mine held up by comparison. Essentially translating into real life the experience of the reflected character trawling through the database. That's some life-imitating-art hype.

From a writing perspective, this is an incredible feat. Straddling ambiguity and clarity, providing a framework which doesn't over-rely on any one narrative element to work. Constructing a story around the freedom of the player to discover any aspect of it at any minute. It's clever stuff.

Don't read any more, just go and play it. It's well worth your time.

The writing for the game greatly complements this by ensuring that the search terms someone might think obvious for a murder investigation don't lead you directly to the biggest twists. The game is also very good about developing our main character through showing rather than telling.

My only notable complaint about the game is that the interface for saved clips is clunkier than it needs to be. Without a way to sort or remove saved clips, trying to find the one you want to rewatch becomes a nightmare once you've spent a while in the game.

TL;DR
Overall, I really enjoyed this game and, like a good mystery novel, I kept spending more time than I intended and staying up late to find out what the next surprise would be. If you like mysteries and unique mechanics/formats for games, I definitely recommend Her Story.

‘Her Story’ tells a lurid crime story with limited interactivity, innovative game-play and a surprising amount of immersion.

The framework of ‘Her Story’ is quickly told: There is a database of video clips, all showing the same woman being interviewed by the police at seven different occasions. You the player can search said database for words, one or more, and it will always return the chronological first five matching clips. That’s it. Now go find out what happened.

These very simple mechanics make this task more of a challenge than you might think. Keep your search terms too common and you only get early clips that don’t explain much. More specific terms might get you snippets out of context, so you have to keep them in mind in order to understand them later. It feels like a mix of detective work, interpreting the woman’s mannerisms and guessing at holes in her story, and hacking, as you try to push the envelope in what the query field can do. It’s very engrossing.

The story told is fascinating and dark, if a bit soap opera. It leads to a satisfying conclusion, even if it doesn’t answer every question and thus leaves room for a lot of interesting, maybe even disturbing speculations.

I found the performance of Viva Seifert absolutely believable, sympathetic and a joy to watch. The score is sparse, but very effective. The aesthetics, while not wowing anyone, are surprisingly immersive. I found myself hunching over the keyboard as if I really was sitting in some dark basement at an old 386 PC, digging through a relic database.

‘Her Story’ also has a great stinger and, to my mind, the best original song since ‘Still alive’.

There is one point where your mileage may vary: Because you have complete freedom over your searches, you might hit upon the major plot points both out of sequence and long before you’ve seen the majority of the clips, which leaves the latter half of the game potentially bereft of satisfying payoffs. The game actually knows this and allows you to trigger the credits manually when you’ve found a certain percentage of videos. It didn’t bother me too much, I found Seifert’s presence so magnetic that I was compelled to hunt down every snippet, even though I already had a complete picture. I actually watched all the clips in order on Youtube right after I completed the game, too.

Additionally the game is rather short. It took me 5 hours to find everything.

In Summary: This game comes highly recommended to fans of FMV, crime stories and experimental storytelling. Gameplay-focused players should look elsewhere.

This game was a really interesting experience. You're set in front of an old pc with recorded interviews of a suspect in a murder case. The records are dated from 1994, and are split into lots of very short videos which are each her answer to a question she's asked, although you don't have the questions. Thanks to the old and fiddly software the database is running on, you can only select videos to watch by searching for words, and you'll bring up the first five videos in which she says the word you searched for. Watching these videos, you might notice she mentions a name or place or other thing that piques your interest, which you can search for to see if she mentions it in other videos, and watching those you might think of something else to search for...

What do you do from there? You can try to solve the murder if you want, make lots of notes and cross-reference all her testimony. Or perhaps you'll find something else you want to explore.

It's a very short mystery, it took me about an hour to really get to the heart of the story, and I carried on for another hour to fill out more of the database and answer a few lingering questions. What's great about this game is how absolutely fascinating the character you're watching is. She's very well constructed, and as you watch the videos, you'll get to know the way she thinks, the things that provoke her, the little strange quirks in her personality, the things that are important to her, and watch the way she changes each day she's brought in for interviews as the case takes its turns. There's no real ending to the game, and you'll have figured things out long before you watch every video, but it's a very rewarding experience and it left me thinking about the story for a long time afterwards.

Sure, its character development, I get it. But due to the sporadic nature of the videos, and because they are not in any specific order, it hampers my ability to empathize with a woman I've only seen for 30 seconds when she starts talking about her mommy issues from childhood. They jump into the cliche "rebel girl" teenage archetype as she regretfully muses about the men she slept with at age 17, but its UNEARNED. These kinds of reveals into a characters flaws and secrets should always be done AFTER the audience has formed some kind of connection with them. Not right off the bat.

The acting of the woman in the videos is sufficient. Its not that she's bad, its that the writing falls short in many ways, which reflects on the character. She's getting interrogated by police but we never see or hear the police talking, which is also a big hit to the story. It would have been much more engaging and interesting if there was a detective asking the questions, ANYONE more than the single girl in the videos would have been nice. 

The gameplay is very simplistic, its just a search engine that you type keywords like "murder" into, and it spits out a new page of videos ranging from short 7 second clips to solid minute monologues about another mundane and generic aspect of her life. As you wade through the horde of videos, your supposed to be learning about the crime and the suspect. Again, the issue here is that there is a metric crap ton of non-pertinent videos with nothing noteworthy in them. The game conveniently has her say the next keywords at the end of the video when your memory is fresh, but it is very easy to lose focus on the details due to the majority of the content being plain boring.

I was super excited to feel like a detective and review a crime in a seemingly realistic way. But the reality was watching video after video of droning monologues and petty details about the kind of wallet her husband has, and how she thinks its real leather... or maybe its fake leather? No its probably real. Oh, and he puts his wallet in his back pocket instead of his front pocket, I told him not to do that! So its probably maybe damaging his back. You know, because of displaced disks and stuff. Like this example, we have a tiny piece of information about a wallet that needs to get expressed, but its done clumsily and without any finesse. She drones about the wallet and this and that, 95% of it is irrelevant and boring, and it feels intentionally stretched to add "content" to the game. This is where it can seem like the actress is just bad at acting, but its what shes working with, a boring script.

The search engine in the game is very archaic, no doubt an intended artistic choice to get the mood right, but it also means your ONLY means of interacting with the game is clunky and ineffective. There is no way to filter results and no way to exclude videos you've already watched. There is some soothing piano music playing in the background, but the interface itself is rather unsightly. Overall for $1.00 its hard to be too bothered by this disappointment. I'm not going to give the game a pass on mediocrity simply because it cost barely any money. 

Its BOOOORING. I'm not some teenager with ADHD, I enjoy slow burn games that parse out tons of lore and details. But Her Story does so in the most bland and monotonous way, my eyes began watering as I steeled myself to withstand the deluge of short clips, each one chipping away at your resolve to push on. Simply not worth it for me, I'm sure there's some great twist or resolution at the end of the rabbit hole, but I doubt I'll ever get there.

60422591.review:
Very intriguing, that's the best way I can describe it. Of course that's neither positive or negative, it's a rather abstract description but I feel that's what fits this experience best.  

The concept is exciting. It doesn't seem to fit any established genre, it relies too heavily on player input that it can't predict or script to be a traditional 'Interactive Movie' or 'Walking Simulator'. But on the flipside that player input doesn't have the depth or range of a 'Point and Click' game. It's singular in it's execution and is exciting for that reason.

Unfortunately that execution is flawed. There are ways to essentially 'break' the game right from the start without ever intending to. It's possible uncover crucial information at the beginning, rendering continued play meaningless. There is no fail state and even the concept of an end is ambiguous to the player. Basically if you approach it like a traditional game with a system that you should be able to exploit, you will be able to and that doesn't sit right with the concept. To get the full, intended experience you need to put yourself in the shoes of the players character, but as by nature you're not given any incite into the character the natural instinct is to 'play' this like a traditional video game. In doing so you lose the intended impact, essentially robbing yourself of the only reason to play this game.

I've had a fascinating experience with it and I highly recommend it. It is flawed, yes, but it's execution is so new, so interesting and individual that it's worth experiencing if just to open your mind to the potential of this medium to tell a story.

I would recommend that you go into this imagining that the character you are playing as is a junior detective or something similar, something to ground you in the idea, and act, of uncovering a mystery you know nothing about. Then when further into the game i'd recommend that you imagine your character is just 'investigating' this for their own enjoyment per se, there is no reason to, they just saw something or maybe remembered something from the past and finally had access to this system. In that way you will able to choose when to 'finish' the game based on when your own personal satisfaction is reached, not when you've 'won', as there is no real end to it, you choose when this ends. Going into this knowing that and creating that idea will help with the worst aspect of this game which is the fact that by design it has no end. There are no game over screens, no 'WINNER' pop ups, it will continue as long as you want it to, remember that and enjoy.

A detective game where you investigate a murder through a series of decade old interviews. The catch: you're using a shoddy database app which has split the interviews into ~70 jumbled clips, can only retrieve clips related to a keyword you provide, and even then only returns the first 5 chronological clips. By latching on to words or phrases, you discover new lines of inquiry and piece together the circumstances behind the murder and interviews.

I was very impressed with how free form the game is - there is nothing stopping you from typing in random words and pulling up twists from an early search, as I did, but the design and writing meant I was just burning to figure out the context and meaning. Each player's path is sure to be unique, as I've found discussing other people's experience with the game, but again the design and writing means that it will always be enjoyable. There is no definite win-state - at a certain point you'll be notified you can leave when you're satisfied, but that's always up to you.

The game is a brilliant showcase of player freedom and non-traditional game structure, which makes it a definite buy for those interested in game design or detective mysteries.

59705909.review:
Definitely an interesting mystery game. You search through the archives of some old police interviews of.... some woman named Hannah? Things aren't very clear at first - or ever, really - because you can't just freely view the videos. You have to search for them, by guessing what words Hannah will say. The archive will only cough up the first five videos in a given search criteria, and there's no easy way to put them in order.

So, you're forced to play connect-the-dots, find key words and search for them to figure out what Hannah's deal is. Definitely cool! It's a good exercise in connected ideas, thinking about what kinds of words are important or significant or likely to get us further results.

Unfortunately, the achievements asking me to try for 100% encouraged me to play long after the fun had worn away. It came to a point where I was just trying every word I could think of, until I finally just gave up and looked up a walkthrough so I could see those last bits. (I still don't know the proper way to get some of the clips, even now) And, at the end of the day, it sure would be nice to be able to view the whole thing in a simple, coherent order, all at once. But then, I suppose that would be counter to the idea in the first place.

Is Her Story a good game? Yes, I think so. I'm glad I played it, but also, I'm glad I only spent $1 on it. It took me under 6 hours to do everything 100%, and I'm not sure the mystery alone is worth $10. I don't know, it's a toss-up at that price. But I love the concept. More games ought to explore the idea of connected ideas like this.

EDIT: Now that I've gone through the story chronologically, I do think the story is good enough to check out. But then, the game offers no easy way to view the interviews in their proper sequence - I had to use an exploit and get a little creative. So, I'm not certain that's relevant data.

55734688.review:
Original and intriguing. 

There is something about FMV games that just draws me in. Maybe it's that I feel like a voyeur peering into someone else's life, or perhaps it's the idea of dealing with real people rather than pixelated sprites, but I'm loving the fact that FMV is making a come back and Her Story is right at the front of the charge. 

This is a game that takes no time to learn, but keeps you wrapped with morbid curiosity for hours as you untangle a web of confusion and possible deception through only one character who changes from one day to the next. 

It's not a spoiler to say that there is more to our witness being interviewed than we might first suspect,  but even that is only the beginning of the puzzle. You will have to figure out how to search for the right keywords, and then piece together the story in true detective fashion to help it make sense, if sense can be made of it. 

There are some barriers to make it more challenging, such as the limit on how many videos you can find at one time, but there is a helpful bar you can use to queue clips of interest. 

The only flaws I felt the game had were that it ends in a clumsy fashion and there is no option to view the entire story from start to finish after you've kind of figured out what happened. I still don't fully understand, but I'm happy not knowing. So much was revealed that made me curious and sometimes it ruins a story to get all the ins and outs of it. 

Well done on another FMV beauty. Please make more. I will pay £ or $ or whatever you want! Anything!

55448411.review:
I absolutely loved Her Story. However, you do need to go into it with a certain mindset, otherwise it will just fall flat. 

I would suggest not to view this as a game. It is more like an interactive environment that has been thoughtfully put together for you to explore. Try to pretend you somehow found these clips on an old computer and let your curiosity drive you. Don't try to brute force yourself to a solution, instead follow the breadcrumbs that the designers have carefully laid out for you. There is no real 'endpoint' to the game; it's finished when you feel your curiosity is quenched. To me, this moment was surprisingly clear: even though I hadn't found 100% of the database, I could tell the story from beginning to end and that did it for me. The 'revelation' at the end confirmed my feelings even more.

The story is excellent and lends itself very well to the concept of the game. Despite the fact that you (in theory) have access to the entire database right from the start, there is hardly a way to 'spoil' the game for yourself. Each clip by itself is not enough to reveal the full story and even if you manage to stumble upon a crucial clip in the very beginning, you will find yourself wondering even more about the underlying motives and background stories. 

Overall, I would absolutely recommend this game, but please look at it for what it is and don't let your expectations of what a 'game' has to be misguide you. This might not be for you and that's okay; but if it is, you're in for a great experience.

54936393.review:
This is one of those games I'm so happy I finally played. Initially, I was skeptical of the FMV-style mystery and assumed it would get really boring just watching a person talk to a camera for hours, but I was captivated the whole way through. 

This game mechanic is simple: it allows you to search through video records of several recorded interview by way of keywords. Watch a few videos, jot down words that sound interesting--a street name, a person, a bar--or even ones that don't, like objects or days of the week. If a keyword is mentioned in a video, that video will appear in the search--but you can only get the top 5-6 most relevant videos at a time, so sometimes, you need to be more specific.

The restriction on only being able to see the top few videos makes it so you can't unlock the story too fast. Generally, that's really effective, but there are definitely some cases where it's darn near impossible to get a video to surface without knowing exactly what you're looking for. But, fortunately, most of those videos aren't essential for unlocking the game's mystery, so you don't need to view everything unless you're a completionist.

I also didn't love that you could save videos in sequence, but that it was nearly impossible to keep them organized. I would have loved if I could have put everything in order from start to finish, then watched it all at the end, but the design of the game made it impossible. However, I [i]did[/i] like that it really feels like you're watching videos on antiquated machines in the basement of some dusty old police station. Between the weird search mechanic, the look of the screen, and the limited functionality of the program, it's definitely immersive. 

As for the story, it's bound to get any curious clicker excited: we have a missing person mystery! And there seems to be one woman at the center of all of it. But how involved is she? Is she guilty? Is there more to the story? 

I love that this game tells the kind of story that has you believing early on that you 100% have it figured out, but as you discover more and more, keeps making you realize things may run deeper than they initially seemed. Absolutely give this one a try!
